1.verse: These are God’s messages to Jeremiah the priest (the son of Hilkiah) who lived in the town of Anathoth in the land of Benjamin. The first of these messages came to him in the thirteenth year of the reign of Amon’s son Josiah, king of Judah.

2.verse: These are God’s messages to Jeremiah the priest (the son of Hilkiah) who lived in the town of Anathoth in the land of Benjamin. The first of these messages came to him in the thirteenth year of the reign of Amon’s son Josiah, king of Judah.

3.verse: Others came during the reign of Josiah’s son Jehoiakim, king of Judah, and at various other times until July of the eleventh year of the reign of Josiah’s son Zedekiah, king of Judah, when Jerusalem was captured and the people were taken away as slaves.

4.verse: The Lord said to me,

5.verse: “I knew you before you were formed within your mother’s womb; before you were born I sanctified you and appointed you as my spokesman to the world.”

6.verse: “O Lord God,” I said, “I can’t do that! I’m far too young! I’m only a youth!”

7.verse: “Don’t say that,” he replied, “for you will go wherever I send you and speak whatever I tell you to.

8.verse: And don’t be afraid of the people, for I, the Lord, will be with you and see you through.”

9.verse: Then he touched my mouth and said, “See, I have put my words in your mouth!

10.verse: Today your work begins, to warn the nations and the kingdoms of the world. In accord with my words spoken through your mouth I will tear down some and destroy them, and plant others, nurture them, and make them strong and great.”

11.verse: Then the Lord said to me, “Look, Jeremiah! What do you see?” And I replied, “I see a whip made from the branch of an almond tree.”

12.verse: And the Lord replied, “That’s right, and it means that I will surely carry out my threats of punishment.”

13.verse: Then the Lord asked me, “What do you see now?” And I replied, “I see a pot of boiling water, tipping southward, spilling over Judah.”

14.verse: “Yes,” he said, “for terror from the north will boil out upon all the people of this land.

15.verse: I am calling the armies of the kingdoms of the north to come to Jerusalem and set their thrones at the gates of the city and all along its walls, and in all the other cities of Judah.

16.verse: This is the way I will punish my people for deserting me and for worshiping other gods—yes, idols they themselves have made!

17.verse: Get up and dress and go out and tell them whatever I tell you to say. Don’t be afraid of them, or else I will make a fool of you in front of them.

18.verse: For see, today I have made you impervious to their attacks. They cannot harm you. You are strong like a fortified city that cannot be captured, like an iron pillar and heavy gates of brass. All the kings of Judah, its officers, priests, and people will not be able to prevail against you.

19.verse: They will try, but they will fail. For I am with you,” says the Lord. “I will deliver you.”

1.verse: Again the Lord spoke to me and said:

2.verse: Go and shout this in Jerusalem’s streets: This is what the Lord says! I remember how eager you were to please me as a young bride long ago, how you loved me and followed me even through the barren deserts.

3.verse: In those days Israel was a holy people, the first of my children. All who harmed them were counted deeply guilty, and great evil fell on anyone who touched them.

4.verse: O Israel, says the Lord, why did your fathers desert me? What sin did they find in me that turned them away and changed them into fools who worship idols?

5.verse: O Israel, says the Lord, why did your fathers desert me? What sin did they find in me that turned them away and changed them into fools who worship idols?

6.verse: They ignore the fact that it was I, the Lord, who brought them safely out of Egypt and led them through the barren wilderness, a land of deserts and rocks, of drought and death, where no one lives or even travels.

7.verse: And I brought them into a fruitful land, to eat of its bounty and goodness, but they made it into a land of sin and corruption and turned my inheritance into an evil thing.

8.verse: Even their priests cared nothing for the Lord, and their judges ignored me; their rulers turned against me, and their prophets worshiped Baal and wasted their time on nonsense.

9.verse: But I will not give you up—I will plead for you to return to me and will keep on pleading; yes, even with your children’s children in the years to come!

10.verse: Look around you and see if you can find another nation anywhere that has traded in its old gods for new ones—even though their gods are nothing. Send to the west to the island of Cyprus; send to the east to the deserts of Kedar. See if anyone there has ever heard so strange a thing as this. And yet my people have given up their glorious God for silly idols!

11.verse: Look around you and see if you can find another nation anywhere that has traded in its old gods for new ones—even though their gods are nothing. Send to the west to the island of Cyprus; send to the east to the deserts of Kedar. See if anyone there has ever heard so strange a thing as this. And yet my people have given up their glorious God for silly idols!

12.verse: The heavens are shocked at such a thing and shrink back in horror and dismay.

13.verse: For my people have done two evil things: They have forsaken me, the Fountain of living waters; and they have built for themselves broken cisterns that can’t hold water!

14.verse: Why has Israel become a nation of slaves? Why is she captured and led far away?

15.verse: I see great armies marching on Jerusalem with mighty shouts to destroy her and leave her cities in ruins, burned and desolate.

16.verse: I see the armies of Egypt rising against her, marching from their cities of Memphis and Tahpanhes to utterly destroy Israel’s glory and power.

17.verse: And you have brought this on yourselves by rebelling against the Lord your God when he wanted to lead you and show you the way!

18.verse: What have you gained by your alliances with Egypt and with Assyria?

19.verse: Your own wickedness will punish you. You will see what an evil, bitter thing it is to rebel against the Lord your God, fearlessly forsaking him, says the Lord Almighty.

20.verse: Long ago you shook off my yoke and broke away from my ties. Defiant, you would not obey me. On every hill and under every tree you’ve bowed low before idols.

21.verse: How could this happen? How could this be? For when I planted you, I chose my seed so carefully—the very best. Why have you become this degenerate race of evil men?

22.verse: No amount of soap or lye can make you clean. You are stained with guilt that cannot ever be washed away. I see it always before me, the Lord God says.

23.verse: You say it isn’t so, that you haven’t worshiped idols? How can you say a thing like that? Go and look in any valley in the land! Face the awful sins that you have done, O restless female camel, seeking for a male!

24.verse: You are a wild donkey, sniffing the wind at mating time. (Who can restrain your lust?) Any jack wanting you need not search, for you come running to him!

25.verse: Why don’t you turn from all this weary running after other gods? But you say, “Don’t waste your breath. I’ve fallen in love with these strangers and I can’t stop loving them now!”

26.verse: Like a thief, the only shame that Israel knows is getting caught. Kings, princes, priests, and prophets—all are alike in this. They call a carved-up wooden post their father, and for their mother they have an idol chiseled out from stone. Yet in time of trouble they cry to me to save them!

27.verse: Like a thief, the only shame that Israel knows is getting caught. Kings, princes, priests, and prophets—all are alike in this. They call a carved-up wooden post their father, and for their mother they have an idol chiseled out from stone. Yet in time of trouble they cry to me to save them!

28.verse: Why don’ you call on these gods you have made? When danger comes, let them go out and save you if they can! For you have as many gods as there are cities in Judah.

29.verse: Don’t come to me—you are all rebels, says the Lord.

30.verse: I have punished your children, but it did them no good; they still will not obey. And you yourselves have killed my prophets as a lion kills its prey.

31.verse: O my people, listen to the words of God: Have I been unjust to Israel? Have I been to them a land of darkness and of evil? Why then do my people say, “At last we are free from God; we won’t have anything to do with him again!”

32.verse: How can you disown your God like that? Can a girl forget her jewels? What bride will seek to hide her wedding dress? Yet for years on end my people have forgotten me—the most precious of their treasures.*

33.verse: How you plot and scheme to win your lovers. The most experienced harlot could learn a lot from you!

34.verse: Your clothing is stained with the blood of the innocent and the poor. Brazenly you murder without a cause.

35.verse: And yet you say, “I haven’t done a thing to anger God. I’m sure he isn’t angry!” I will punish you severely because you say, “I haven’t sinned!”

36.verse: First here, then there, you flit about, going from one ally to another for their help; but it’s all no good—your new friends in Egypt will forsake you as Assyria did before.

37.verse: You will be left in despair and cover your face with your hands, for the Lord has rejected the ones that you trust. You will not succeed despite their aid.

1.verse: There is a law that if a man divorces a woman who then remarries, he is not to take her back again, for she has become corrupted. But though you have left me and married many lovers, yet I have invited you to come to me again, the Lord says.

2.verse: Is there a single spot in all the land where you haven’t been defiled by your adulteries—your worshiping these other gods? You sit like a prostitute beside the road waiting for a client! You sit alone like a Bedouin in the desert. You have polluted the land with your vile prostitution.

3.verse: That is why even the springtime rains have failed. For you are a prostitute and completely unashamed.

4.verse: And yet you say to me, “O Father, you have always been my Friend; surely you won’t be angry about such a little thing! Surely you will just forget it?” So you talk and keep right on doing all the evil that you can.

5.verse: And yet you say to me, “O Father, you have always been my Friend; surely you won’t be angry about such a little thing! Surely you will just forget it?” So you talk and keep right on doing all the evil that you can.

6.verse: This message from the Lord came to me during the reign of King Josiah: Have you seen what Israel does? Like a wanton wife who gives herself to other men at every chance, so Israel has worshiped other gods on every hill, beneath every shady tree.

7.verse: I thought that someday she would return to me and once again be mine; but she didn’t come back. And her faithless sister Judah saw the continued rebellion of Israel.

8.verse: Yet she paid no attention, even though she saw that I divorced faithless Israel. But now Judah too has left me and given herself to prostitution, for she has gone to other gods to worship them.

9.verse: She treated it all so lightly—to her it was nothing at all that she should worship idols made of wood and stone. And so the land was greatly polluted and defiled.

10.verse: Then, afterwards, this faithless one “returned” to me, but her “sorrow” was only faked, the Lord God says.

11.verse: In fact, faithless Israel is less guilty than treacherous Judah!

12.verse: Therefore, go and say to Israel, O Israel, my sinful people, come home to me again, for I am merciful; I will not be forever angry with you.

13.verse: Only acknowledge your guilt; admit that you rebelled against the Lord your God and committed adultery against him by worshiping idols under every tree; confess that you refused to follow me.

14.verse: O sinful children, come home, for I am your Master, and I will bring you again to the land of Israel—one from here and two from there, wherever you are scattered.

15.verse: And I will give you leaders after my own heart, who will guide you with wisdom and understanding.

16.verse: Then, when your land is once more filled with people, says the Lord, you will no longer wish for “the good old days of long ago” when you possessed the Ark of God’s covenant. Those days will not be missed or even thought about, and the Ark will not be reconstructed, for the Lord himself will be among you.

17.verse: The whole city of Jerusalem will be known as the throne of the Lord; all nations will come to him there and no longer stubbornly follow their evil desires.

18.verse: At that time the people of Judah and of Israel will return together from their exile in the north, to the land I gave their fathers as an inheritance forever.

19.verse: And I thought how wonderful it would be for you to be here among my children. I planned to give you part of this beautiful land, the finest in the world. I looked forward to your calling me “Father” and thought that you would never turn away from me again.

20.verse: But you have betrayed me; you have gone off and given yourself to a host of foreign gods; you have been like a faithless wife who leaves her husband.

21.verse: I hear a voice high upon the windswept mountains, crying, crying. It is the sons of Israel who have turned their backs on God and wandered far away.

22.verse: O my rebellious children, come back to me again and I will heal you from your sins. And they reply, Yes, we will come, for you are the Lord our God.

23.verse: We are weary of worshiping idols on the hills and of having orgies on the mountains. It is all a farce. Only in the Lord our God can Israel ever find her help and her salvation.

24.verse: From our childhood we have seen everything our fathers had—flocks and herds and sons and daughters—squandered on priests and idols.

25.verse: We lie in shame and in dishonor, for we and our fathers have sinned from childhood against the Lord our God; we have not obeyed him.

1.verse: O Israel, if you will truly return to me and absolutely discard your idols,

2.verse: and if you will swear by me alone, the living God, and begin to live good, honest, clean lives, then you will be a testimony to the nations of the world, and they will come to me and glorify my name.

3.verse: The Lord is saying to the men of Judah and Jerusalem, Plow up the hardness of your hearts; otherwise the good seed will be wasted among the thorns.

4.verse: Cleanse your minds and hearts, not just your bodies, or else my anger will burn you to a crisp because of all your sins. And no one will be able to put the fire out.

5.verse: Shout to Jerusalem and to all Judea, telling them to sound the alarm throughout the land. “Run for your lives! Flee to the fortified cities!”

6.verse: Send a signal from Jerusalem: “Flee now, don’t delay!” For I the Lord am bringing vast destruction on you from the north.

7.verse: A lion—a destroyer of nations—stalks from his lair; and he is headed for your land. Your cities will lie in ruin without inhabitant.

8.verse: Put on clothes of mourning and weep with broken hearts, for the fierce anger of the Lord has not stopped yet.

9.verse: In that day, says the Lord, the king and the princes will tremble in fear; and the priests and the prophets will be stricken with horror.

10.verse: (Then I said, “But Lord, the people have been deceived by what you said, for you promised great blessings on Jerusalem. Yet the sword is even now poised to strike them dead!”)

11.verse: At that time he will send a burning wind from the desert upon them—not in little gusts but in a roaring blast—and he will pronounce their doom.

12.verse: At that time he will send a burning wind from the desert upon them—not in little gusts but in a roaring blast—and he will pronounce their doom.

13.verse: The enemy shall roll down upon us like a storm wind; his chariots are like a whirlwind; his steeds are swifter than eagles. Woe, woe upon us, for we are doomed.

14.verse: O Jerusalem, cleanse your hearts while there is time. You can yet be saved by casting out your evil thoughts.

15.verse: From Dan and from Mount Ephraim your doom has been announced.

16.verse: Warn the other nations that the enemy is coming from a distant land, and they shout against Jerusalem and the cities of Judah.

17.verse: They surround Jerusalem like shepherds moving in on some wild animal! For my people have rebelled against me, says the Lord.

18.verse: Your ways have brought this down upon you; it is a bitter dose of your own medicine, striking deep within your hearts.

19.verse: My heart, my heart—I writhe in pain; my heart pounds within me. I cannot be still because I have heard, O my soul, the blast of the enemies’ trumpets and the enemies’ battle cries.

20.verse: Wave upon wave of destruction rolls over the land, until it lies in utter ruin; suddenly, in a moment, every house is crushed.

21.verse: How long must this go on? How long must I see war and death surrounding me?

22.verse: “Until my people leave their foolishness, for they refuse to listen to me; they are dull, retarded children who have no understanding. They are smart enough at doing wrong, but for doing right they have no talent, none at all.”

23.verse: I looked down upon their land, and as far as I could see in all directions everything was ruins. And all the heavens were dark.

24.verse: I looked at the mountains and saw that they trembled and shook.

25.verse: I looked, and mankind was gone, and the birds of the heavens had fled.

26.verse: The fertile valleys were wilderness, and all the cities were broken down before the presence of the Lord, crushed by his fierce anger.

27.verse: The Lord’s decree of desolation covers all the land. “Yet,” he says, “there will be a little remnant of my people left.

28.verse: The earth shall mourn, the heavens shall be draped with black, because of my decree against my people; I have made up my mind and will not change it.”

29.verse: All the cities flee in terror at the noise of marching armies coming near. The people hide in the bushes and flee to the mountains. All the cities are abandoned—all have fled in terror.

30.verse: Why do you put on your most beautiful clothing and jewelry and brighten your eyes with mascara? It will do you no good! Your allies despise you and will kill you.

31.verse: I have heard great crying like that of a woman giving birth to her first child; it is the cry of my people gasping for breath, pleading for help, prostrate before their murderers.

1.verse: Run up and down through every street in all Jerusalem; search high and low and see if you can find even one person who is fair and honest! Search every square, and if you find just one, I’ll not destroy the city!

2.verse: Even under oath, they all lie.

3.verse: O Lord, you are looking for faithfulness. You have tried to get them to be honest, for you have punished them, but they won’t change! You have destroyed them, but they refuse to turn from their sins. They are determined, with faces hard as rock, not to repent.

4.verse: Then I said, “But what can we expect from the poor and ignorant? They don’t know the ways of God. How can they obey him?”

5.verse: I will go now to their leaders, the men of importance, and speak to them, for they know the ways of the Lord and the judgment that follows sin. But they too had utterly rejected their God.

6.verse: So I will send upon them the wild fury of the “lion from the forest”; the “desert wolves” shall pounce upon them, and a “leopard” shall lurk around their cities so that all who go out shall be torn apart. For their sins are very many; their rebellion against me is great.

7.verse: How can I pardon you? For even your children have turned away and worship gods that are not gods at all. I fed my people until they were fully satisfied, and their thanks was to commit adultery wholesale and to gang up at the city’s brothels.

8.verse: They are well-fed, lusty stallions, each neighing for his neighbor’s mate.

9.verse: Shall I not punish them for this? Shall I not send my vengeance on such a nation as this?

10.verse: Go down the rows of the vineyards and destroy them! But leave a scattered few to live. Strip the branches from each vine, for they are not the Lord’s.

11.verse: For the people of Israel and Judah are full of treachery against me, says the Lord.

12.verse: They have lied and said, “He won’t bother us! No evil will come upon us! There will be neither famine nor war!

13.verse: God’s prophets,” they say, “are windbags full of words with no divine authority. Their claims of doom will fall upon themselves, not us!”

14.verse: Therefore, this is what the Lord God of Hosts says to his prophets: Because of talk like this, I’ll take your words and prophecies and turn them into raging fire and burn up these people like kindling wood.

15.verse: See, I will bring a distant nation against you, O Israel, says the Lord. It is a mighty nation, an ancient nation whose language you don’t understand.

16.verse: Their weapons are deadly; the men are all mighty.

17.verse: And they shall eat your harvest and your children’s bread, your flocks of sheep and herds of cattle, yes, and your grapes and figs; and they shall sack your walled cities that you think are safe.

18.verse: But I will not completely blot you out. So says the Lord.

19.verse: And when your people ask, “Why is it that the Lord is doing this to us?” then you shall say, “You rejected him and gave yourselves to other gods while in your land; now you must be slaves to foreigners in their lands.”

20.verse: Make this announcement to Judah and to Israel:

21.verse: Listen, O foolish, senseless people—you with the eyes that do not see and the ears that do not listen—

22.verse: have you no respect at all for me? the Lord God asks. How can it be that you don’t even tremble in my presence? I set the shorelines of the world by perpetual decrees, so that the oceans, though they toss and roar, can never pass those bounds. Isn’t such a God to be feared and worshiped?

23.verse: But my people have rebellious hearts; they have turned against me and gone off into idolatry. Though I am the one who gives them rain each year in spring and fall and sends the harvesttimes, yet they have no respect or fear for me.

24.verse: But my people have rebellious hearts; they have turned against me and gone off into idolatry. Though I am the one who gives them rain each year in spring and fall and sends the harvesttimes, yet they have no respect or fear for me.

25.verse: And so I have taken away these wondrous blessings from them. This sin has robbed them of all of these good things.

26.verse: Among my people are wicked men who lurk for victims like a hunter hiding in a blind. They set their traps for men.

27.verse: Like a coop full of chickens their homes are full of evil plots. And the result? Now they are great and rich,

28.verse: they are well fed and well groomed, and there is no limit to their wicked deeds. They refuse justice to orphans and the rights of the poor.

29.verse: Should I sit back and act as though nothing is going on? the Lord God asks. Shouldn’t I punish a nation such as this?

30.verse: A horrible thing has happened in this land—

31.verse: the priests are ruled by false prophets, and my people like it so! But your doom is certain.

1.verse: Run, people of Benjamin, run for your lives! Flee from Jerusalem! Sound the alarm in Tekoa; send up a smoke signal at Beth-haccherem; warn everyone that a powerful army is on the way from the north, coming to destroy this nation!

2.verse: Helpless as a girl, you are beautiful and delicate—and doomed.

3.verse: Evil shepherds shall surround you. They shall set up camp around the city and divide your pastures for their flocks.

4.verse: See them prepare for battle. At noon it has begun. All afternoon it rages until the evening shadows fall.

5.verse: “Come,” they say. “Let us attack by night and destroy her palaces!”

6.verse: For the Lord Almighty has said to them, Cut down her trees for battering rams; smash down the walls of Jerusalem. This is the city to be punished, for she is vile through and through.

7.verse: She spouts evil like a fountain! Her streets echo with the sounds of violence; her sickness and wounds are ever before me.

8.verse: This is your last warning, O Jerusalem. If you don’t listen, I will empty the land.

9.verse: Disaster on disaster shall befall you. Even the few who remain in Israel shall be gleaned again, the Lord Almighty has said; for as a grape-gatherer checks each vine to pick what he has missed, so the remnant of my people shall be destroyed again.

10.verse: But who will listen when I warn them? Their ears are closed, and they refuse to hear. The word of God has angered them; they don’t want it at all.

11.verse: For all this I am full of the wrath of God against them. I am weary of holding it in. I will pour it out over Jerusalem, even upon the children playing in the streets, upon the gatherings of young men, and on husbands and wives and grandparents.

12.verse: Their enemies shall live in their homes and take their fields and wives. For I will punish the people of this land, the Lord has said.

13.verse: They are swindlers and liars, from the least of them right to the top! Yes, even my prophets and priests!

14.verse: You can’t heal a wound by saying it’s not there! Yet the priests and prophets give assurances of peace when all is war.

15.verse: Were my people ashamed when they worshiped idols? No, not at all—they didn’t even blush. Therefore they shall lie among the slain. They shall die beneath my anger.

16.verse: Yet the Lord pleads with you still: Ask where the good road is, the godly paths you used to walk in, in the days of long ago. Travel there, and you will find rest for your souls. But you reply, “No, that is not the road we want!”

17.verse: I set watchmen over you who warned you: “Listen for the sound of the trumpet! It will let you know when trouble comes.” But you said, “No! We won’t pay any attention!”

18.verse: This, then, is my decree against my people: (Listen to it, distant lands; listen to it, O my people in Jerusalem; listen to it, all the earth!) I will bring evil upon this people; it will be the fruit of their own sin because they will not listen to me. They reject my law.

19.verse: This, then, is my decree against my people: (Listen to it, distant lands; listen to it, O my people in Jerusalem; listen to it, all the earth!) I will bring evil upon this people; it will be the fruit of their own sin because they will not listen to me. They reject my law.

20.verse: There is no use now in burning sweet incense from Sheba before me! Keep your expensive perfumes! I cannot accept your offerings; they have no sweet fragrance for me.

21.verse: I will make an obstacle course of the pathway of my people; fathers and sons shall be frustrated; neighbors and friends shall collapse together.

22.verse: The Lord God says: See the armies marching from the north—a great nation is rising against you.

23.verse: They are a cruel, merciless people, fully armed, mounted for war. The noise of their army is like a roaring sea.

24.verse: We have heard the fame of their armies, and we are weak with fright. Fright and pain have gripped us like that of women in travail.

25.verse: Don’t go out to the fields! Don’t travel the roads! For the enemy is everywhere, ready to kill; we are terrorized at every turn.

26.verse: O Jerusalem, pride of my people, put on mourning clothes and sit in ashes; weep bitterly as for an only son. For suddenly the destroying armies will be upon you.

27.verse: Jeremiah, I have made you an assayer of metals that you may test this my people and determine their value. Listen to what they are saying and watch what they are doing.

28.verse: Are they not the worst of rebels, full of evil talk against the Lord? They are insolent as brass, hard and cruel as iron.

29.verse: The bellows blow fiercely; the refining fire grows hotter, but it can never cleanse them, for there is no pureness in them to bring out. Why continue the process longer? All is dross. No matter how hot the fire, they continue in their wicked ways.

30.verse: I must label them “Impure, Rejected Silver,” and I have discarded them.

1.verse: Then the Lord said to Jeremiah:

2.verse: Go over to the entrance of the Temple of the Lord and give this message to the people: O Judah, listen to this message from God. Listen to it, all of you who worship here.

3.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel says: Even yet, if you quit your evil ways, I will let you stay in your own land.

4.verse: But don’t be fooled by those who lie to you and say that since the Temple of the Lord is here, God will never let Jerusalem be destroyed.

5.verse: You may remain under these conditions only: If you stop your wicked thoughts and deeds and are fair to others;

6.verse: if you stop exploiting orphans, widows, and foreigners, and stop your murdering; if you stop worshiping idols as you do now to your hurt,

7.verse: then, and only then, will I let you stay in this land that I gave to your fathers to keep forever.

8.verse: You think that because the Temple is here, you will never suffer? Don’t fool yourselves!

9.verse: Do you really think that you can steal, murder, commit adultery, lie, and worship Baal and all of those new gods of yours,

10.verse: and then come here and stand before me in my Temple and chant, “We are saved!”—only to go right back to all these evil things again?

11.verse: Is my Temple but a den of robbers in your eyes? For I see all the evil going on in there.

12.verse: Go to Shiloh, the city I first honored with my name, and see what I did to her because of all the wickedness of my people Israel.

13.verse: And now, says the Lord, I will do the same thing here because of all this evil you have done. Again and again I spoke to you about it, rising up early and calling, but you refused to hear or answer. Yes, I will destroy this Temple, as I did in Shiloh—this Temple called by my name, which you trust for help, and this place I gave to you and to your fathers.

14.verse: And now, says the Lord, I will do the same thing here because of all this evil you have done. Again and again I spoke to you about it, rising up early and calling, but you refused to hear or answer. Yes, I will destroy this Temple, as I did in Shiloh—this Temple called by my name, which you trust for help, and this place I gave to you and to your fathers.

15.verse: And I will send you into exile, just as I did your brothers, the people of Ephraim.

16.verse: Pray no more for these people, Jeremiah. Neither weep for them nor pray nor beg that I should help them, for I will not listen.

17.verse: Don’t you see what they are doing throughout the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?

18.verse: No wonder my anger is great! Watch how the children gather wood and the fathers build fires, and the women knead dough and make cakes to offer to the Queen of Heaven and to their other idol-gods!

19.verse: Am I the one that they are hurting? asks the Lord. Most of all they hurt themselves, to their own shame.

20.verse: So the Lord God says: I will pour out my anger, yes, my fury on this place—people, animals, trees, and plants will be consumed by the unquenchable fire of my anger.

21.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel says: Away with your offerings and sacrifices!

22.verse: It wasn’t offerings and sacrifices I wanted from your fathers when I led them out of Egypt. That was not the point of my command.

23.verse: But what I told them was: Obey me, and I will be your God and you shall be my people; only do as I say, and all shall be well!

24.verse: But they wouldn’t listen; they kept on doing whatever they wanted to, following their own stubborn, evil thoughts. They went backward instead of forward.

25.verse: Ever since the day your fathers left Egypt until now, I have kept on sending them my prophets, day after day.

26.verse: But they wouldn’t listen to them or even try to hear. They are hard and stubborn and rebellious—worse even than their fathers were.

27.verse: Tell them everything that I will do to them, but don’t expect them to listen. Cry out your warnings, but don’t expect them to respond.

28.verse: Say to them: “This is the nation that refuses to obey the Lord its God and refuses to be taught. She continues to live a lie.”

29.verse: O Jerusalem, shave your head in shame and weep alone upon the mountains; for the Lord has rejected and forsaken this people of his wrath.

30.verse: For the people of Judah have sinned before my very eyes, says the Lord. They have set up their idols right in my own Temple, polluting it.

31.verse: They have built the altar called Topheth in the valley of Ben-hinnom, and there they burn to death their little sons and daughters as sacrifices to their gods—a deed so horrible I’ve never even thought of it, let alone commanded it to be done.

32.verse: The time is coming, says the Lord, when that valley’s name will be changed from Topheth or Ben-hinnom Valley, to the Valley of Slaughter; for there will be so many slain to bury that there won’t be room enough for all the graves, and they will dump the bodies in that valley.

33.verse: The bodies of my people shall be food for the birds and animals, and no one shall be left to scare them away.

34.verse: I will end the happy singing and laughter and the joyous voices of the bridegrooms and brides in the streets of Jerusalem and in the cities of Judah. For the land shall lie in desolation.

1.verse: Then, says the Lord, the enemy shall break open the graves of the kings of Judah and of the princes, and the graves of the priests, prophets, and people,

2.verse: and dig out their bones and spread them out on the ground before the sun and moon and stars—the gods of my people!—whom they have loved and worshiped. Their bones shall not be gathered up again nor buried but shall be scattered like dung upon the ground.

3.verse: And those of this evil nation who are still left alive shall long to die rather than live where I will scatter them, says the Lord Almighty.

4.verse: Once again give them this message from the Lord: When a person falls, he jumps up again; when he is on the wrong road and discovers his mistake, he goes back to the fork where he made the wrong turn. But these people keep on along their evil path, even though I warn them.

5.verse: Once again give them this message from the Lord: When a person falls, he jumps up again; when he is on the wrong road and discovers his mistake, he goes back to the fork where he made the wrong turn. But these people keep on along their evil path, even though I warn them.

6.verse: I listen to their conversation and what do I hear? Is anyone sorry for sin? Does anyone say, “What a terrible thing I have done”? No, all are rushing pell-mell down the path of sin as swiftly as a horse rushing to the battle!

7.verse: The stork knows the time of her migration, as does the turtledove, the crane, and the swallow. They all return at God’s appointed time each year; but not my people! They don’t accept the laws of God.

8.verse: How can you say, “We understand his laws,” when your teachers have twisted them up to mean a thing I never said?

9.verse: These wise teachers of yours will be shamed by exile for this sin, for they have rejected the word of the Lord. Are they then so wise?

10.verse: I will give their wives and their farms to others; for all of them, great and small, prophet and priest, have one purpose in mind—to get what isn’t theirs.

11.verse: They give useless medicine for my people’s grievous wounds, for they assure them all is well when that isn’t so at all!

12.verse: Are they ashamed because they worship idols? No, not in the least; they don’t even know how to blush! That is why I will see to it that they lie among the fallen. I will visit them with death.

13.verse: Their figs and grapes will disappear, their fruit trees will die, and all the good things I prepared for them will soon be gone.

14.verse: Then the people will say, “Why should we wait here to die? Come, let us go to the walled cities and perish there. For the Lord our God has decreed our doom and given us a cup of poison to drink because of all our sins.

15.verse: We expected peace, but no peace came; we looked for health, but there was only terror.”

16.verse: The noise of war resounds from the northern border. The whole land trembles at the approach of the terrible army, for the enemy is coming and is devouring the land and everything in it—the cities and people alike.

17.verse: For I will send these enemy troops among you like poisonous snakes that you cannot charm. No matter what you do, they will bite you and you shall die.

18.verse: My grief is beyond healing; my heart is broken.

19.verse: Listen to the weeping of my people all across the land. “Where is the Lord?” they ask. “Has God deserted us?” “Oh, why have they angered me with their carved idols and strange evil rites?” the Lord replies.

20.verse: “The harvest is finished; the summer is over, and we are not saved.”

21.verse: I weep for the hurt of my people; I stand amazed, silent, dumb with grief.

22.verse: Is there no medicine in Gilead? Is there no physician there? Why doesn’t God do something? Why doesn’t he help?

1.verse: Oh, that my eyes were a fountain of tears; I would weep forever; I would sob day and night for the slain of my people!

2.verse: Oh, that I could go away and forget them and live in some wayside shack in the desert, for they are all adulterous, treacherous men.

3.verse: “They bend their tongues like bows to shoot their arrows of untruth. They care nothing for right and go from bad to worse; they care nothing for me,” says the Lord.

4.verse: Beware of your neighbor! Beware of your brother! All take advantage of one another and spread their slanderous lies.

5.verse: With practiced tongues they fool and defraud each other; they wear themselves out with all their sinning.

6.verse: “They pile evil upon evil, lie upon lie, and utterly refuse to come to me,” says the Lord.

7.verse: Therefore, the Lord Almighty says this: “See, I will melt them in a crucible of affliction. I will refine them and test them like metal. What else can I do with them?

8.verse: For their tongues aim lies like poisoned spears. They speak cleverly to their neighbors while planning to kill them.

9.verse: Should not I punish them for such things as this?” asks the Lord. “Shall not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this?”

10.verse: Sobbing and weeping, I point to their mountains and pastures, for now they are desolate, without a living soul. Gone is the lowing of cattle, gone the birds and wild animals. All have fled.

11.verse: “And I will turn Jerusalem into heaps of ruined houses where only jackals have their dens. The cities of Judah shall be ghost towns, with no one living in them.”

12.verse: Who is wise enough to understand all this? Where is the Lord’s messenger to explain it? Why is the land a wilderness so that no one dares even to travel through?

13.verse: “Because,” the Lord replies, “my people have forsaken my commandments and not obeyed my laws.

14.verse: Instead, they have done whatever they pleased and worshiped the idols of Baal, as their fathers told them to.”

15.verse: Therefore, this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Look! I will feed them with bitterness and give them poison to drink.

16.verse: I will scatter them around the world, to be strangers in distant lands; and even there the sword of destruction shall chase them until I have utterly destroyed them.

17.verse: The Lord Almighty says: “Send for the mourners! Quick! Begin your crying! Let the tears flow from your eyes.

18.verse: The Lord Almighty says: “Send for the mourners! Quick! Begin your crying! Let the tears flow from your eyes.

19.verse: Hear Jerusalem weeping in despair. ‘We are ruined! Disaster has befallen us! We must leave our land and homes!’”

20.verse: Listen to the words of God, O women who wail. Teach your daughters to wail and your neighbors too.

21.verse: For death has crept in through your windows into your homes. He has killed off the flower of your youth. Children no longer play in the streets; the young men gather no more in the squares.

22.verse: Tell them this, says the Lord: Bodies shall be scattered across the fields like manure, like sheaves after the mower, and no one will bury them.

23.verse: The Lord says: Let not the wise man bask in his wisdom, nor the mighty man in his might, nor the rich man in his riches.

24.verse: Let them boast in this alone: That they truly know me, and understand that I am the Lord of justice and of righteousness whose love is steadfast; and that I love to be this way.

25.verse: A time is coming, says the Lord, when I will punish all those who are circumcised in body but not in spirit—the Egyptians, Edomites, Ammonites, Moabites, Arabs, and yes, even you people of Judah. For all these pagan nations also circumcise themselves. Unless you circumcise your hearts by loving me, your circumcision is only a heathen rite like theirs, and nothing more.

26.verse: A time is coming, says the Lord, when I will punish all those who are circumcised in body but not in spirit—the Egyptians, Edomites, Ammonites, Moabites, Arabs, and yes, even you people of Judah. For all these pagan nations also circumcise themselves. Unless you circumcise your hearts by loving me, your circumcision is only a heathen rite like theirs, and nothing more.

1.verse: Hear the word of the Lord, O Israel:

2.verse: Don’t act like the people who make horoscopes and try to read their fate and future in the stars! Don’t be frightened by predictions such as theirs, for it is all a pack of lies. Their ways are futile and foolish. They cut down a tree and carve an idol;

3.verse: Don’t act like the people who make horoscopes and try to read their fate and future in the stars! Don’t be frightened by predictions such as theirs, for it is all a pack of lies. Their ways are futile and foolish. They cut down a tree and carve an idol;

4.verse: they decorate it with gold and silver and fasten it securely in place with hammer and nails so that it won’t fall over.

5.verse: And there stands their god like a helpless scarecrow in a garden! It cannot speak, and it must be carried, for it cannot walk. Don’t be afraid of such a god, for it can neither harm nor help nor do you any good.

6.verse: O Lord, there is no other god like you. For you are great, and your name is full of power.

7.verse: Who would not fear you, O King of nations? (And that title belongs to you alone!) Among all the wise men of the earth and in all the kingdoms of the world there isn’t anyone like you.

8.verse: The wisest of men who worship idols are altogether stupid and foolish.

9.verse: They bring beaten sheets of silver from Tarshish and gold from Uphaz and give them to skillful goldsmiths who make their idols; then they clothe these gods in royal purple robes that expert tailors make.

10.verse: But the Lord is the only true God, the living God, the everlasting King. The whole earth shall tremble at his anger; the world shall hide before his displeasure.

11.verse: Say this to those who worship other gods: Your so-called gods, who have not made the heavens and earth, shall vanish from the earth.

12.verse: But our God formed the earth by his power and wisdom, and by his intelligence he hung the stars in space and stretched out the heavens.

13.verse: It is his voice that echoes in the thunder of the storm clouds. He causes mist to rise upon the earth; he sends the lightning and brings the rain, and from his treasuries he brings the wind.

14.verse: But foolish men without knowledge of God bow before their idols. It is a shameful business that these men are in, for what they make are frauds, gods without life or power in them.

15.verse: All are worthless, silly; they will be crushed when their makers perish.

16.verse: But the God of Jacob is not like these foolish idols. He is the Creator of all, and Israel is his chosen nation. The Lord Almighty is his name.

17.verse: Pack your bags, he says. Get ready now to leave; the siege will soon begin.

18.verse: For suddenly I’ll fling you from this land and pour great troubles down; at last you shall feel my wrath.

19.verse: Desperate is my wound. My grief is great. My sickness is incurable, but I must bear it.

20.verse: My home is gone; my children have been taken away, and I will never see them again. There is no one left to help me rebuild my home.

21.verse: The shepherds of my people have lost their senses; they no longer follow God nor ask his will. Therefore they perish, and their flocks are scattered.

22.verse: Listen! Hear the terrible sound of great armies coming from the north. The cities of Judah shall become dens of jackals.

23.verse: O Lord, I know it is not within the power of man to map his life and plan his course—

24.verse: so you correct me, Lord; but please be gentle. Don’t do it in your anger, for I would die.

25.verse: Pour out your fury on the nations who don’t obey the Lord, for they have destroyed Israel and made a wasteland of this entire country.

1.verse: Then the Lord spoke to Jeremiah once again and said: Remind the men of Judah and all the people of Jerusalem that I made a contract with their fathers—and cursed is the man who does not heed it!

2.verse: Then the Lord spoke to Jeremiah once again and said: Remind the men of Judah and all the people of Jerusalem that I made a contract with their fathers—and cursed is the man who does not heed it!

3.verse: Then the Lord spoke to Jeremiah once again and said: Remind the men of Judah and all the people of Jerusalem that I made a contract with their fathers—and cursed is the man who does not heed it!

4.verse: For I told them at the time I brought them out of slavery in Egypt that if they would obey me and do whatever I commanded them, then they and all their children would be mine and I would be their God.

5.verse: And now, Israel, obey me, says the Lord, so that I can do for you the wonderful things I swore I would if you obeyed. I want to give you a land that “flows with milk and honey,” as it is today. Then I replied, “So be it, Lord!”

6.verse: Then the Lord said: Broadcast this message in Jerusalem’s streets—go from city to city throughout the land and say, Remember this agreement that your fathers made with God, and do all the things they promised him they would.

7.verse: For I solemnly said to your fathers when I brought them out of Egypt—and have kept on saying it over and over again until this day: Obey my every command!

8.verse: But your fathers didn’t do it. They wouldn’t even listen. Each followed his own stubborn will and his proud heart. Because they refused to obey, I did to them all the evils stated in the contract.

9.verse: Again the Lord spoke to me and said: I have discovered a conspiracy against me among the men of Judah and Jerusalem.

10.verse: They have returned to the sins of their fathers, refusing to listen to me and worshiping idols. The agreement I made with their fathers is broken and canceled.

11.verse: Therefore, the Lord says, I am going to bring calamity down upon them, and they shall not escape. Though they cry for mercy, I will not listen to their pleas.

12.verse: Then they will pray to their idols and burn incense before them, but that cannot save them from their time of anguish and despair.

13.verse: O my people, you have as many gods as there are cities, and your altars of shame (your altars to burn incense to Baal) are along every street in Jerusalem.

14.verse: Therefore, Jeremiah, pray no longer for this people, neither weep nor plead for them; for I will not listen to them when they are finally desperate enough to beg me for help.

15.verse: What right do my beloved people have to come anymore to my Temple? For you have been unfaithful and worshiped other gods. Can promises and sacrifices now avert your doom and give you life and joy again?

16.verse: The Lord used to call you his green olive tree, beautiful to see and full of good fruit; but now he has sent the fury of your enemies to burn you up and leave you broken and charred.

17.verse: It is because of the wickedness of Israel and Judah in offering incense to Baal that the Lord Almighty who planted the tree has ordered it destroyed.

18.verse: Then the Lord told me all about their plans and showed me their evil plots.

19.verse: I had been as unsuspecting as a lamb or ox on the way to slaughter. I didn’t know that they were planning to kill me! “Let’s destroy this man and all his messages,” they said. “Let’s kill him so that his name will be forever forgotten.”

20.verse: O Lord Almighty, you are just. See the hearts and motives of these men. Repay them for all that they have planned! I look to you for justice.

21.verse: And the Lord replied, The men of the city of Anathoth shall be punished for planning to kill you. They will tell you not to prophesy in God’s name on pain of death. And so their young men shall die in battle; their boys and girls shall starve.

22.verse: And the Lord replied, The men of the city of Anathoth shall be punished for planning to kill you. They will tell you not to prophesy in God’s name on pain of death. And so their young men shall die in battle; their boys and girls shall starve.

23.verse: Not one of these plotters of Anathoth shall survive, for I will bring a great disaster upon them. Their time has come.

1.verse: O Lord, you always give me justice when I bring a case before you to decide. Now let me bring you this complaint: Why are the wicked so prosperous? Why are evil men so happy?

2.verse: You plant them. They take root and their business grows. Their profits multiply, and they are rich. They say, “Thank God!” But in their hearts they give no credit to you.

3.verse: But as for me—Lord, you know my heart—you know how much it longs for you. (And I am poor, O Lord!) Lord, drag them off like helpless sheep to the slaughter. Judge them, O God!

4.verse: How long must this land of yours put up with all their goings-on? Even the grass of the field groans and weeps over their wicked deeds! The wild animals and birds have moved away, leaving the land deserted. Yet the people say, “God won’t bring judgment on us. We’re perfectly safe!”

5.verse: The Lord replied to me: If racing with mere men—these men of Anathoth—has wearied you, how will you race against horses, against the king, his court, and all his evil priests? If you stumble and fall on open ground, what will you do in Jordan’s jungles?

6.verse: Even your own brothers, your own family, have turned against you. They have plotted to call for a mob to lynch you. Don’t trust them, no matter how pleasantly they speak. Don’t believe them.

7.verse: Then the Lord said: I have abandoned my people, my inheritance; I have surrendered my dearest ones to their enemies.

8.verse: My people have roared at me like a lion of the forest, so I have treated them as though I hated them.

9.verse: My people have fallen. I will bring upon them swarms of vultures and wild animals to pick the flesh from their corpses.

10.verse: Many foreign rulers have ravaged my vineyard, trampling down the vines, and turning all its beauty into barren wilderness.

11.verse: They have made it desolate; I hear its mournful cry. The whole land is desolate and no one cares.

12.verse: Destroying armies plunder the land; the sword of the Lord devours from one end of the nation to the other; nothing shall escape.

13.verse: My people have sown wheat but reaped thorns; they have worked hard, but it does them no good. They shall harvest a crop of shame, for the fierce anger of the Lord is upon them.

14.verse: And now the Lord says this to the evil nations, the nations surrounding the land God gave his people Israel: See, I will force you from your land just as Judah will be forced from hers;

15.verse: but afterwards I will return and have compassion on all of you and will bring you home to your own land again, each man to his inheritance.

16.verse: And if these heathen nations quickly learn my people’s ways and claim me as their God instead of Baal (whom they taught my people to worship), then they shall be strong among my people.

17.verse: But any nation refusing to obey me will be expelled again and finished, says the Lord.

1.verse: The Lord said to me, Go and buy a linen loincloth and wear it, but don’t wash it—don’t put it in water at all.

2.verse: So I bought the loincloth and put it on.

3.verse: Then the Lord’s message came to me again. This time he said,

4.verse: Take the loincloth out to the Euphrates River and hide it in a hole in the rocks.

5.verse: So I did; I hid it as the Lord had told me to.

6.verse: Then, a long time afterwards, the Lord said: Go out to the river again and get the loincloth.

7.verse: And I did; I dug it out of the hole where I had hidden it. But now it was mildewed and falling apart. It was utterly useless!

8.verse: Then the Lord said: This illustrates the way that I will rot the pride of Judah and Jerusalem.

9.verse: Then the Lord said: This illustrates the way that I will rot the pride of Judah and Jerusalem.

10.verse: This evil nation refuses to listen to me and follows its own evil desires, and worships idols; therefore, it shall become as this loincloth—good for nothing.

11.verse: Even as a loincloth clings to a man’s loins, so I made Judah and Israel to cling to me, says the Lord. They were my people, an honor to my name. But then they turned away.

12.verse: Tell them this: The Lord God of Israel says, All your wine jugs will be full of wine. And they will reply, Of course, you don’t need to tell us how prosperous we will be!

13.verse: Then tell them: That’s not what I mean. I mean that I will fill everyone living in this land with helpless bewilderment—from the king sitting on David’s throne, and the priests and the prophets, right on down to all the people.

14.verse: And I will smash fathers and sons against each other, says the Lord. I will not let pity nor mercy spare them from utter destruction.

15.verse: Oh, that you were not so proud and stubborn! Then you would listen to the Lord, for he has spoken.

16.verse: Give glory to the Lord your God before it is too late, before he causes deep, impenetrable darkness to fall upon you so that you stumble and fall upon the dark mountains; then, when you look for light, you will find only terrible darkness.

17.verse: Do you still refuse to listen? Then in loneliness my breaking heart shall mourn because of your pride. My eyes will overflow with tears because the Lord’s flock shall be carried away as slaves.

18.verse: Say to the king and queen mother, Come down from your thrones and sit in the dust, for your glorious crowns are removed from your heads. They are no longer yours.

19.verse: The cities of the Negeb to the south of Jerusalem have closed their gates against the enemy. They must defend themselves, for Jerusalem cannot help; and all Judah shall be taken away as slaves.

20.verse: See the armies marching from the north! Where is your flock, Jerusalem, your beautiful flock he gave you to take care of ?

21.verse: How will you feel when he sets your allies over you as your rulers? You will writhe in pain like a woman having a child.

22.verse: And if you ask yourself, Why is all this happening to me? It is because of the grossness of your sins; that is why you have been raped and destroyed by the invading army.

23.verse: Can the Ethiopian change the color of his skin? or a leopard take away his spots? Nor can you who are so used to doing evil now start being good.

24.verse: Because you have put me out of your mind and put your trust in false gods, I will scatter you as chaff is scattered by the fierce winds off the desert. This then is your allotment, that which is due you, which I have measured out especially for you.

25.verse: Because you have put me out of your mind and put your trust in false gods, I will scatter you as chaff is scattered by the fierce winds off the desert. This then is your allotment, that which is due you, which I have measured out especially for you.

26.verse: I myself will expose you to utter shame.

27.verse: I am keenly aware of your apostasy, your faithlessness to me, and your abominable idol worship in the fields and on the hills. Woe upon you, O Jerusalem! How long before you will be pure?

1.verse: This message came to Jeremiah from the Lord, explaining why he was holding back the rain:

2.verse: Judah mourns; business has ground to a halt; all the people prostrate themselves to the earth, and a great cry rises from Jerusalem.

3.verse: The nobles send servants for water from the wells, but the wells are dry. The servants return, baffled and desperate, and cover their heads in grief.

4.verse: The ground is parched and cracked for lack of rain; the farmers are afraid.

5.verse: The deer deserts her fawn because there is no grass.

6.verse: The wild donkeys stand upon the bare hills panting like thirsty jackals. They strain their eyes looking for grass to eat, but there is none to be found.

7.verse: O Lord, we have sinned against you grievously, yet help us for the sake of your own reputation!

8.verse: O Hope of Israel, our Savior in times of trouble, why are you as a stranger to us, as one passing through the land who is merely stopping for the night?

9.verse: Are you also baffled? Are you helpless to save us? O Lord, you are right here among us, and we carry your name; we are known as your people. O Lord, don’t desert us now!

10.verse: But the Lord replies: You have loved to wander far from me and have not tried to follow in my paths. Now I will no longer accept you as my people; now I will remember all the evil you have done and punish your sins.

11.verse: The Lord told me again: Don’t ask me anymore to bless this people. Don’t pray for them anymore.

12.verse: When they fast, I will not pay any attention; when they present their offerings and sacrifices to me, I will not accept them. What I will give them in return is war and famine and disease.

13.verse: Then I said, O Lord God, their prophets are telling them that all is well—that no war or famine will come. They tell the people you will surely send them peace, that you will bless them.

14.verse: Then the Lord said: The prophets are telling lies in my name. I didn’t send them or tell them to speak or give them any message. They prophesy of visions and revelations they have never seen nor heard; they speak foolishness concocted out of their own lying hearts.

15.verse: Therefore, the Lord says, I will punish these lying prophets who have spoken in my name though I did not send them, who say no war shall come nor famine. By war and famine they themselves shall die!

16.verse: And the people to whom they prophesy—their bodies shall be thrown out into the streets of Jerusalem, victims of famine and war; there shall be no one to bury them. Husbands, wives, sons, and daughters—all will be gone. For I will pour out terrible punishment upon them for their sins.

17.verse: Therefore, tell them this: Night and day my eyes shall overflow with tears; I cannot stop my crying, for my people have been run through with a sword and lie mortally wounded on the ground.

18.verse: If I go out in the fields, there lie the bodies of those the sword has killed; and if I walk in the streets, there lie those dead from starvation and disease. And yet the prophets and priests alike have made it their business to travel through the whole country, reassuring everyone that all is well, speaking of things they know nothing about.

19.verse: “O Lord,” the people will cry, “have you completely rejected Judah? Do you abhor Jerusalem? Even after punishment, will there be no peace? We thought, Now at last he will heal us and bind our wounds. But no peace has come, and there is only trouble and terror everywhere.

20.verse: O Lord, we confess our wickedness, and that of our fathers too.

21.verse: Do not hate us, Lord, for the sake of your own name. Do not disgrace yourself and the throne of your glory by forsaking your promise to bless us!

22.verse: What heathen god can give us rain? Who but you alone, O Lord our God, can do such things as this? Therefore we will wait for you to help us.”

1.verse: Then the Lord said to me, Even if Moses and Samuel stood before me pleading for these people, even then I wouldn’t help them—away with them! Get them out of my sight!

2.verse: And if they say to you, But where can we go? Tell them the Lord says: Those who are destined for death, to death; those who must die by the sword, to the sword; those doomed to starvation, to famine; and those for captivity, to captivity.

3.verse: I will appoint over them four kinds of destroyers, says the Lord: the sword to kill, the dogs to tear, and the vultures and wild animals to finish up what’s left.

4.verse: Because of the wicked things Manasseh, son of Hezekiah, king of Judah, did in Jerusalem, I will punish you so severely that your fate will horrify the peoples of the world.

5.verse: Who will feel sorry for you, Jerusalem? Who will weep for you? Who will even bother to ask how you are?

6.verse: You have forsaken me and turned your backs upon me. Therefore, I will clench my fists against you to destroy you. I am tired of always giving you another chance.

7.verse: I will sift you at the gates of your cities and take from you all that you hold dear, and I will destroy my own people because they refuse to turn back to me from all their evil ways.

8.verse: There shall be countless widows; at noontime I will bring death to the young men and sorrow to their mothers. I will cause anguish and terror to fall upon them suddenly.

9.verse: The mother of seven sickens and faints, for all her sons are dead. Her sun is gone down while it is yet day. She sits childless now, disgraced, for all her children have been killed.

10.verse: Then Jeremiah said, “What sadness is mine, my mother; oh, that I had died at birth. For I am hated everywhere I go. I am neither a creditor soon to foreclose nor a debtor refusing to pay—yet they all curse me.

11.verse: Well, let them curse! Lord, you know how I have pled with you on their behalf—how I have begged you to spare these enemies of mine.”

12.verse: Can a man break bars of northern iron or bronze? This people’s stubborn will can’t be broken either. So, because of all your sins against me, I will deliver your wealth and treasures as loot to the enemy.

13.verse: Can a man break bars of northern iron or bronze? This people’s stubborn will can’t be broken either. So, because of all your sins against me, I will deliver your wealth and treasures as loot to the enemy.

14.verse: I will have your enemies take you as slaves to a land where you have never been before, for my anger burns like fire, and it shall consume you.

15.verse: Then Jeremiah replied, “Lord, you know it is for your sake that I am suffering. They are persecuting me because I have proclaimed your word to them. Don’t let them kill me! Rescue me from their clutches, and give them what they deserve!

16.verse: Your words are what sustain me; they are food to my hungry soul. They bring joy to my sorrowing heart and delight me. How proud I am to bear your name, O Lord.

17.verse: I have not joined the people in their merry feasts. I sit alone beneath the hand of God. I burst with indignation at their sins. Yet you have failed me in my time of need! You have let them keep right on with all their persecutions. Will they never stop hurting me? Your help is as uncertain as a seasonal mountain brook—sometimes a flood, sometimes as dry as a bone.”

18.verse: I have not joined the people in their merry feasts. I sit alone beneath the hand of God. I burst with indignation at their sins. Yet you have failed me in my time of need! You have let them keep right on with all their persecutions. Will they never stop hurting me? Your help is as uncertain as a seasonal mountain brook—sometimes a flood, sometimes as dry as a bone.”

19.verse: The Lord replied: “Stop this foolishness and talk some sense! Only if you return to trusting me will I let you continue as my spokesman. You are to influence them, not let them influence you!

20.verse: They will fight against you like a besieging army against a high city wall. But they will not conquer you, for I am with you to protect and deliver you, says the Lord.

21.verse: Yes, I will certainly deliver you from these wicked men and rescue you from their ruthless hands.”

1.verse: On yet another occasion God spoke to me, and said:

2.verse: You must not marry and have children here.

3.verse: For the children born in this city and their mothers and fathers

4.verse: shall die from terrible diseases. No one shall mourn for them or bury them, but their bodies shall lie on the ground to rot and fertilize the soil. They shall die from war and famine, and their bodies shall be picked apart by vultures and wild animals.

5.verse: Do not mourn or weep for them, for I have removed my protection and my peace from them—taken away my loving-kindness and my mercies.

6.verse: Both great and small shall die in this land, unburied and unmourned, and their friends shall not cut themselves nor shave their heads as signs of sorrow (as is their heathen custom).

7.verse: No one shall comfort the mourners with a meal nor send them a cup of wine expressing grief for their parents’ death.

8.verse: As a sign to them of these sad days ahead, don’t you join them anymore in their feasts and parties—don’t even eat a meal with them.

9.verse: For the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: In your own lifetime, before your very eyes, I will end all laughter in this land—the happy songs, the marriage feasts, the songs of bridegrooms and of brides.

10.verse: And when you tell the people all these things and they ask, “Why has the Lord decreed such terrible things against us? What have we done to merit such treatment? What is our sin against the Lord our God?”

11.verse: tell them the Lord’s reply is this: Because your fathers forsook me. They worshiped other gods and served them; they did not keep my laws,

12.verse: and you have been worse than your fathers were! You follow evil to your hearts’ content and refuse to listen to me.

13.verse: Therefore, I will throw you out of this land and chase you into a foreign land where neither you nor your fathers have been before, and there you can go ahead and worship your idols all you like—and I will grant you no favors!

14.verse: But there will come a glorious day, says the Lord, when the whole topic of conversation will be that God is bringing his people home from a nation in the north, and from many other lands where he had scattered them. You will look back no longer to the time when I rescued you from your slavery in Egypt. That mighty miracle will scarcely be mentioned anymore. Yes, I will bring you back again, says the Lord, to this same land I gave your fathers.

15.verse: But there will come a glorious day, says the Lord, when the whole topic of conversation will be that God is bringing his people home from a nation in the north, and from many other lands where he had scattered them. You will look back no longer to the time when I rescued you from your slavery in Egypt. That mighty miracle will scarcely be mentioned anymore. Yes, I will bring you back again, says the Lord, to this same land I gave your fathers.

16.verse: Now I am sending for many fishermen to fish you from the deeps where you are hiding from my wrath. I am sending for hunters to chase you down like deer in the forests or mountain goats on inaccessible crags. Wherever you run to escape my judgment, I will find you and punish you.

17.verse: For I am closely watching you, and I see every sin. You cannot hope to hide from me.

18.verse: And I will punish you doubly for all your sins because you have defiled my land with your detestable idols and filled it up with all your evil deeds.

19.verse: O Lord, my Strength and Fortress, my Refuge in the day of trouble, nations from around the world will come to you saying, “Our fathers have been foolish, for they have worshiped worthless idols!

20.verse: Can men make God? The gods they made are not real gods at all.”

21.verse: And when they come in that spirit, I will show them my power and might and make them understand at last that I alone am God.

1.verse: My people sin as though commanded to, as though their evil were laws chiseled with an iron pen or diamond point upon their stony hearts or on the corners of their altars.

2.verse: Their youths do not forget to sin, worshiping idols beneath each tree, high in the mountains or in the open country down below. And so I will give all your treasures to your enemies as the price that you must pay for all your sins.

3.verse: Their youths do not forget to sin, worshiping idols beneath each tree, high in the mountains or in the open country down below. And so I will give all your treasures to your enemies as the price that you must pay for all your sins.

4.verse: And the wonderful heritage I reserved for you will slip out of your hand, and I will send you away as slaves to your enemies in distant lands. For you have kindled a fire of my anger that shall burn forever.

5.verse: The Lord says: Cursed is the man who puts his trust in mortal man and turns his heart away from God.

6.verse: He is like a stunted shrub in the desert, with no hope for the future; he lives on the salt-encrusted plains in the barren wilderness; good times pass him by forever.

7.verse: But blessed is the man who trusts in the Lord and has made the Lord his hope and confidence.

8.verse: He is like a tree planted along a riverbank, with its roots reaching deep into the water—a tree not bothered by the heat nor worried by long months of drought. Its leaves stay green, and it goes right on producing all its luscious fruit.

9.verse: The heart is the most deceitful thing there is and desperately wicked. No one can really know how bad it is!

10.verse: Only the Lord knows! He searches all hearts and examines deepest motives so he can give to each person his right reward, according to his deeds—how he has lived.

11.verse: Like a bird that fills her nest with young she has not hatched and which will soon desert her and fly away, so is the man who gets his wealth by unjust means. Sooner or later he will lose his riches and at the end of his life become a poor old fool.

12.verse: But our refuge is your throne, eternal, high, and glorious.

13.verse: O Lord, the Hope of Israel, all who turn away from you shall be disgraced and shamed; they are registered for earth and not for glory, for they have forsaken the Lord, the Fountain of living waters.

14.verse: Lord, you alone can heal me, you alone can save, and my praises are for you alone.

15.verse: Men scoff at me and say, “What is this word of the Lord you keep talking about? If these threats of yours are really from God, why don’t they come true?”

16.verse: Lord, I don’t want the people crushed by terrible calamity. The plan is yours, not mine. It is your message I’ve given them, not my own. I don’t want them doomed!

17.verse: Lord, don’t desert me now! You alone are my hope.

18.verse: Bring confusion and trouble on all who persecute me, but give me peace. Yes, bring double destruction upon them!

19.verse: Then the Lord said to me, Go and stand in the gates of Jerusalem, first at the gate where the king goes out, and then at each of the other gates,

20.verse: and say to all the people: Hear the word of the Lord, kings of Judah and all the people of this nation, and all you citizens of Jerusalem.

21.verse: The Lord says: Take warning and live; do no unnecessary work on the Sabbath day, but make it a holy day. I gave this commandment to your fathers,

22.verse: The Lord says: Take warning and live; do no unnecessary work on the Sabbath day, but make it a holy day. I gave this commandment to your fathers,

23.verse: but they didn’t listen or obey. They stubbornly refused to pay attention and be taught.

24.verse: But if you obey me, says the Lord, and refuse to work on the Sabbath day and keep it separate, special and holy,

25.verse: then this nation shall continue forever. There shall always be descendants of David sitting on the throne here in Jerusalem; there shall always be kings and princes riding in pomp and splendor among the people, and this city shall remain forever.

26.verse: And from all around Jerusalem and from the cities of Judah and Benjamin, from the Negeb and from the lowlands west of Judah, the people shall come with their burnt offerings and grain offerings and incense, bringing their sacrifices to praise the Lord in his Temple.

27.verse: But if you will not listen to me, if you refuse to keep the Sabbath holy, if on the Sabbath you bring in loads of merchandise through these gates of Jerusalem, just as on other days, then I will set fire to these gates. The fire shall spread to the palaces and utterly destroy them, and no one shall be able to put out the raging flames.

1.verse: Here is another message to Jeremiah from the Lord:

2.verse: Go down to the shop where clay pots and jars are made, and I will talk to you there.

3.verse: I did as he told me and found the potter working at his wheel.

4.verse: But the jar that he was forming didn’t turn out as he wished, so he kneaded it into a lump and started again.

5.verse: Then the Lord said:

6.verse: O Israel, can’t I do to you as this potter has done to his clay? As the clay is in the potter’s hand, so are you in my hand.

7.verse: Whenever I announce that a certain nation or kingdom is to be taken up and destroyed,

8.verse: then if that nation renounces its evil ways, I will not destroy it as I had planned.

9.verse: And if I announce that I will make a certain nation strong and great,

10.verse: but then that nation changes its mind, turns to evil, and refuses to obey me, then I, too, will change my mind and not bless that nation as I had said I would.

11.verse: Therefore, go and warn all Judah and Jerusalem, saying: Hear the word of the Lord. I am planning evil against you now instead of good; turn back from your evil paths and do what is right.

12.verse: But they replied, “Don’t waste your breath. We have no intention whatever of doing what God says. We will continue to live as we want to, free from any restraint, full of stubbornness and wickedness!”

13.verse: Then the Lord said: Even among the heathen, no one has ever heard of such a thing! My people have done something too horrible to understand.

14.verse: The snow never melts high up in the Lebanon mountains. The cold, flowing streams from the crags of Mount Hermon never run dry.

15.verse: These can be counted on. But not my people! For they have deserted me and turned to foolish idols. They have turned away from the ancient highways of good and walk the muddy paths of sin.

16.verse: Therefore, their land shall become desolate, so that all who pass by will gasp and shake their heads in amazement at its utter desolation.

17.verse: I will scatter my people before their enemies as the east wind scatters dust; and in all their trouble I will turn my back on them and refuse to notice their distress.

18.verse: Then the people said, “Come, let’s get rid of Jeremiah. We have our own priests and wise men and prophets—we don’t need his advice. Let’s silence him that he may speak no more against us, nor bother us again.”

19.verse: O Lord, help me! See what they are planning to do to me!

20.verse: Should they repay evil for good? They have set a trap to kill me, yet I spoke well of them to you and tried to defend them from your anger.

21.verse: Now, Lord, let their children starve to death and let the sword pour out their blood! Let their wives be widows and be bereft of all their children! Let their men die in epidemics and their youths die in battle!

22.verse: Let screaming be heard from their homes as troops of soldiers come suddenly upon them, for they have dug a pit for me to fall in, and they have hidden traps along my path.

23.verse: Lord, you know all their murderous plots against me. Don’t forgive them, don’t blot out their sin, but let them perish before you; deal with them in your anger.

1.verse: The Lord said, Buy a clay jar and take it out into the valley of Ben-hinnom by the east gate of the city. Take some of the elders of the people and some of the older priests with you, and speak to them whatever words I give you.

2.verse: The Lord said, Buy a clay jar and take it out into the valley of Ben-hinnom by the east gate of the city. Take some of the elders of the people and some of the older priests with you, and speak to them whatever words I give you.

3.verse: Then the Lord spoke to them and said: Listen to the word of the Lord, kings of Judah and citizens of Jerusalem! The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: I will bring terrible evil upon this place, so terrible that the ears of those who hear it will prickle.

4.verse: For Israel has forsaken me and turned this valley into a place of shame and wickedness. The people burn incense to idols—idols that neither this generation nor their forefathers nor the kings of Judah have worshiped before—and they have filled this place with the blood of innocent children.

5.verse: They have built high altars to Baal, and there they burn their sons in sacrifice—a thing I never commanded them nor even thought of !

6.verse: The day is coming, says the Lord, when this valley shall no longer be called Topheth or Ben-hinnom Valley, but the Valley of Slaughter.

7.verse: For I will upset the battle plans of Judah and Jerusalem, and I will let invading armies kill you here and leave your dead bodies for vultures and wild animals to feed upon.

8.verse: And I will wipe Jerusalem off the earth, so that everyone going by will gasp with astonishment at all that I have done to her.

9.verse: I will see to it that your enemies lay siege to the city until all food is gone and those trapped inside begin to eat their own children and friends.

10.verse: And now, Jeremiah, as these men watch, smash the jar you brought with you,

11.verse: and say to them, This is the message to you from the Lord Almighty: As this jar lies shattered, so I will shatter the people of Jerusalem; and as this jar cannot be mended, neither can they. The slaughter shall be so great that there won’t be room enough for decent burial anywhere, and their bodies shall be heaped in this valley.

12.verse: And as it will be in this valley, so it will be in Jerusalem. For I will fill Jerusalem with dead bodies too.

13.verse: And I will defile all the homes in Jerusalem, including the palace of the kings of Judah—wherever incense has been burned upon the roofs to your star gods, and libations poured out to them.

14.verse: As Jeremiah returned from Topheth where he had delivered this message, he stopped in front of the Temple of the Lord and said to all the people,

15.verse: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: I will bring upon this city and her surrounding towns all the evil I have promised because you have stubbornly refused to listen to the Lord.

1.verse: Now when Pashhur (son of Immer), the priest in charge of the Temple of the Lord, heard what Jeremiah was saying,

2.verse: he arrested Jeremiah and had him whipped and put in the stocks at Benjamin Gate near the Temple.
