3.verse: He left him there all night. The next day when Pashhur finally released him, Jeremiah said, “Pashhur, the Lord has changed your name. He says from now on to call you ‘The Man Who Lives in Terror.’

4.verse: For the Lord will send terror on you and all your friends, and you will see them die by the swords of their enemies. I will hand over Judah to the king of Babylon, says the Lord, and he shall take away these people as slaves to Babylon and kill them.

5.verse: And I will let your enemies loot Jerusalem. All the famed treasures of the city, with the precious jewels and gold and silver of your kings, shall be carried off to Babylon.

6.verse: And as for you, Pashhur, you and all your family and household shall become slaves in Babylon and die there—you and those to whom you lied when you prophesied that everything would be all right.”

7.verse: O Lord, you deceived me when you promised me your help. I have to give them your messages because you are stronger than I am, but now I am the laughingstock of the city, mocked by all.

8.verse: You have never once let me speak a word of kindness to them; always it is disaster and horror and destruction. No wonder they scoff and mock and make my name a household joke.

9.verse: And I can’t quit! For if I say I’ll never again mention the Lord—never more speak in his name—then his word in my heart is like fire that burns in my bones, and I can’t hold it in any longer.

10.verse: Yet on every side I hear their whispered threats and am afraid. “We will report,” they say. Even those who were my friends are watching me, waiting for a fatal slip. “He will trap himself,” they say, “and then we will get our revenge on him.”

11.verse: But the Lord stands beside me like a great warrior, and before him, the Mighty, Terrible One, they shall stumble. They cannot defeat me; they shall be shamed and thoroughly humiliated, and they shall have a stigma upon them forever.

12.verse: O Lord Almighty, who knows those who are righteous and examines the deepest thoughts of hearts and minds, let me see your vengeance on them. For I have committed my cause to you.

13.verse: Therefore, I will sing out in thanks to the Lord! Praise him! For he has delivered me, poor and needy, from my oppressors.

14.verse: Yet, cursed be the day that I was born!

15.verse: Cursed be the man who brought my father the news that a son was born.

16.verse: Let that messenger be destroyed like the cities of old which God overthrew without mercy. Terrify him all day long with battle shouts

17.verse: because he did not kill me at my birth! Oh, that I had died within my mother’s womb, that it had been my grave!

18.verse: Why was I ever born? For my life has been but trouble and sorrow and shame.

1.verse: Then King Zedekiah sent Pashhur (son of Malchiah) and Zephaniah the priest (son of Maaseiah) to Jeremiah and begged, “Ask the Lord to help us, for Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, has declared war on us!

2.verse: Perhaps the Lord will be gracious to us and do a mighty miracle as in olden times and force Nebuchadnezzar to withdraw his forces.”

3.verse: Jeremiah replied, “Go back to King Zedekiah and tell him the Lord God of Israel says, I will make all your weapons useless against the king of Babylon and the Chaldeans besieging you. In fact, I will bring your enemies right into the heart of this city,

4.verse: Jeremiah replied, “Go back to King Zedekiah and tell him the Lord God of Israel says, I will make all your weapons useless against the king of Babylon and the Chaldeans besieging you. In fact, I will bring your enemies right into the heart of this city,

5.verse: and I myself will fight against you, for I am very angry.

6.verse: And I will send a terrible plague on this city, and both men and animals shall die.

7.verse: And finally I will deliver King Zedekiah himself and all the remnant left in the city into the hands of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, to slaughter them without pity or mercy.

8.verse: “Tell these people: This is what the Lord says! Take your choice of life or death!

9.verse: Stay here in Jerusalem and die—slaughtered by your enemies, killed by starvation and disease—or go out and surrender to the Chaldean army and live.

10.verse: For I have set my face against this city; I will be its enemy and not its friend, says the Lord. It shall be captured by the king of Babylon and he shall reduce it to ashes.

11.verse: “And to the king of Judah, the Lord says:

12.verse: I am ready to judge you because of all the evil you are doing. Quick! Give justice to these you judge! Begin doing what is right before my burning fury flashes out upon you like a fire no man can quench.

13.verse: I will fight against this city of Jerusalem that boasts, ‘We are safe; no one can touch us here!’

14.verse: And I myself will destroy you for your sinfulness, says the Lord. I will light a fire in the forests that will burn up everything in its path.”

1.verse: Then the Lord said to me: Go over and speak directly to the king of Judah and say,

2.verse: Listen to this message from God, O king of Judah, sitting on David’s throne; and let your servants and your people listen too.

3.verse: The Lord says: Be fair-minded. Do what is right! Help those in need of justice! Quit your evil deeds! Protect the rights of aliens and immigrants, orphans and widows; stop murdering the innocent!

4.verse: If you put an end to all these terrible deeds you are doing, then I will deliver this nation and once more give kings to sit on David’s throne, and there shall be prosperity for all.

5.verse: But if you refuse to pay attention to this warning, I swear by my own name, says the Lord, that this palace shall become a shambles.

6.verse: For this is the Lord’s message concerning the palace: You are as beloved to me as fruitful Gilead and the green forests of Lebanon; but I will destroy you and leave you deserted and uninhabited.

7.verse: I will call for a wrecking crew to bring out its tools to dismantle you. They will tear out all of your fine cedar beams and throw them on the fire.

8.verse: Men from many nations will pass by the ruins of this city and say to one another, “Why did the Lord do it? Why did he destroy such a great city?”

9.verse: And the answer will be, “Because the people living here forgot the Lord their God and violated his agreement with them, for they worshiped idols.”

10.verse: Don’t weep for the dead! Instead weep for the captives led away! For they will never return to see their native land again.

11.verse: For the Lord says this about Jehoahaz who succeeded his father King Josiah and was taken away as a captive:

12.verse: He shall die in a distant land and never again see his own country.

13.verse: And woe to you, King Jehoiakim, for you are building your great palace with forced labor. By not paying wages you are building injustice into its walls and oppression into its doorframes and ceilings.

14.verse: You say, “I will build a magnificent palace with huge rooms and many windows, paneled throughout with fragrant cedar and painted a lovely red.”

15.verse: But a beautiful palace does not make a great king! Why did your father Josiah reign so long? Because he was just and fair in all his dealings. That is why God blessed him.

16.verse: He saw to it that justice and help were given the poor and the needy and all went well for him. This is how a man lives close to God.

17.verse: But you! You are full of selfish greed and all dishonesty! You murder the innocent, oppress the poor, and reign with ruthlessness.

18.verse: Therefore this is God’s decree of punishment against King Jehoiakim, who succeeded his father Josiah on the throne: His family will not weep for him when he dies. His subjects will not even care that he is dead.

19.verse: He shall be buried like a dead donkey—dragged out of Jerusalem and thrown on the garbage dump beyond the gate!

20.verse: Weep, for your allies are gone. Search for them in Lebanon; shout for them at Bashan; seek them at the fording points of Jordan. See, they are all destroyed. Not one is left to help you!

21.verse: When you were prosperous, I warned you, but you replied, “Don’t bother me.” Since childhood you have been that way—you just won’t listen!

22.verse: And now all your allies have disappeared with a puff of wind; all your friends are taken off as slaves. Surely at last you will see your wickedness and be ashamed.

23.verse: It’s very nice to live graciously in a beautiful palace among the cedars of Lebanon, but soon you will cry and groan in anguish—anguish as of a woman in labor.

24.verse: And as for you, Coniah, son of Jehoiakim king of Judah—even if you were the signet ring on my right hand, I would pull you off and give you to those who seek to kill you, of whom you are so desperately afraid—to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and his mighty army.

25.verse: And as for you, Coniah, son of Jehoiakim king of Judah—even if you were the signet ring on my right hand, I would pull you off and give you to those who seek to kill you, of whom you are so desperately afraid—to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and his mighty army.

26.verse: I will throw you and your mother out of this country, and you shall die in a foreign land.

27.verse: You will never again return to the land of your desire.

28.verse: This man Coniah is like a discarded, broken dish. He and his children will be exiled to distant lands.

29.verse: O earth, earth, earth! Hear the word of the Lord!

30.verse: The Lord says: Record this man Coniah as childless, for none of his children shall ever sit upon the throne of David or rule in Judah. His life will amount to nothing.

1.verse: The Lord declares: I will send disaster upon the leaders of my people—the shepherds of my sheep—for they have destroyed and scattered the very ones they were to care for.

2.verse: Instead of leading my flock to safety, you have deserted them and driven them to destruction. And now I will pour out judgment upon you for the evil you have done to them.

3.verse: And I will gather together the remnant of my flock from wherever I have sent them and bring them back into their own fold, and they shall be fruitful and increase.

4.verse: And I will appoint responsible shepherds to care for them, and they shall not need to be afraid again; all of them shall be accounted for continually.

5.verse: For the time is coming, says the Lord, when I will place a righteous Branch upon King David’s throne. He shall be a King who shall rule with wisdom and justice and cause righteousness to prevail everywhere throughout the earth. And this is his name: The Lord Our Righteousness. At that time Judah will be saved and Israel will live in peace.

6.verse: For the time is coming, says the Lord, when I will place a righteous Branch upon King David’s throne. He shall be a King who shall rule with wisdom and justice and cause righteousness to prevail everywhere throughout the earth. And this is his name: The Lord Our Righteousness. At that time Judah will be saved and Israel will live in peace.

7.verse: In that day people will no longer say when taking an oath, “As the Lord lives who rescued the people of Israel from the land of Egypt,”

8.verse: but they will say, “As the Lord lives who brought the Jews back to their own land of Israel from the countries to which he had exiled them.”

9.verse: My heart is broken for the false prophets, full of deceit. I awake with fear and stagger as a drunkard does from wine because of the awful fate awaiting them, for God has decreed holy words of judgment against them.

10.verse: For the land is full of adultery, and the curse of God is on it. The land itself is mourning—the pastures are dried up—for the prophets do evil, and their power is used wrongly.

11.verse: The priests are like the prophets, all ungodly, wicked men. I have seen their despicable acts right here in my own Temple, says the Lord.

12.verse: Therefore, their paths will be dark and slippery; they will be chased down dark and treacherous trails and fall. For I will bring evil upon them and see to it, when their time has come, that they pay their penalty in full for all their sins.

13.verse: I knew the prophets of Samaria were unbelievably evil, for they prophesied by Baal and led my people Israel into sin;

14.verse: but the prophets of Jerusalem are even worse! The things they do are horrible; they commit adultery and love dishonesty. They encourage and compliment those who are doing evil instead of turning them back from their sins. These prophets are as thoroughly depraved as the men of Sodom and Gomorrah were.

15.verse: Therefore the Lord Almighty says: I will feed them with bitterness and give them poison to drink. For it is because of them that wickedness fills this land.

16.verse: This is my warning to my people, says the Lord Almighty. Don’t listen to these false prophets when they prophesy to you, filling you with futile hopes. They are making up everything they say. They do not speak for me!

17.verse: They keep saying to these rebels who despise me, “Don’t worry! All is well!”; and to those who live the way they want to, “The Lord has said you shall have peace!”

18.verse: But can you name even one of these prophets who lives close enough to God to hear what he is saying? Has even one of them cared enough to listen?

19.verse: See, the Lord is sending a furious whirlwind to sweep away these wicked men.

20.verse: The terrible anger of the Lord will not abate until it has carried out the full penalty he decrees against them. Later, when Jerusalem has fallen, you will see what I mean.

21.verse: I have not sent these prophets, yet they claim to speak for me; I gave them no message, yet they say their words are mine.

22.verse: If they were mine, they would try to turn my people from their evil ways.

23.verse: Am I a God who is only in one place and cannot see what they are doing?

24.verse: Can anyone hide from me? Am I not everywhere in all of heaven and earth?

25.verse: “Listen to the dream I had from God last night,” they say. And then they proceed to lie in my name.

26.verse: How long will this continue? If they are “prophets,” they are prophets of deceit, inventing everything they say.

27.verse: By telling these false dreams they are trying to get my people to forget me in the same way as their fathers did, who turned away to the idols of Baal.

28.verse: Let these false prophets tell their dreams and let my true messengers faithfully proclaim my every word. There is a difference between chaff and wheat!

29.verse: Does not my word burn like fire? asks the Lord. Is it not like a mighty hammer that smashed the rock to pieces?

30.verse: So I stand against these “prophets” who get their messages from each other—these smooth-tongued “prophets” who say, “This message is from God!”

31.verse: So I stand against these “prophets” who get their messages from each other—these smooth-tongued “prophets” who say, “This message is from God!”

32.verse: Their made-up dreams are flagrant lies that lead my people into sin. I did not send them, and they have no message at all for my people, says the Lord.

33.verse: When one of the people or one of their “prophets” or priests asks you, “Well, Jeremiah, what is the sad news from the Lord today?” you shall reply, “What sad news? You are the sad news, for the Lord has cast you away!”

34.verse: And as for the false prophets and priests and people who joke about “today’s sad news from God,” I will punish them and their families for saying this.

35.verse: You can ask each other, “What is God’s message? What is he saying?”

36.verse: But stop using this term, “God’s sad news.” For what is sad is you and your lying. You are twisting my words and inventing “messages from God” that I didn’t speak.

37.verse: You may respectfully ask Jeremiah, “What is the Lord’s message? What has he said to you?”

38.verse: But if you ask him about “today’s sad news from God,” when I have warned you not to mock like that, then I, the Lord God, will unburden myself of the burden you are to me. I will cast you out of my presence, you and this city I gave to you and your fathers.

39.verse: But if you ask him about “today’s sad news from God,” when I have warned you not to mock like that, then I, the Lord God, will unburden myself of the burden you are to me. I will cast you out of my presence, you and this city I gave to you and your fathers.

40.verse: And I will bring reproach upon you and your name shall be infamous through the ages.

1.verse: After Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, had captured and enslaved Jeconiah (son of Jehoiakim), king of Judah, and exiled him to Babylon along with the princes of Judah and the skilled tradesmen—the carpenters and blacksmiths—the Lord gave me this vision.

2.verse: I saw two baskets of figs placed in front of the Temple in Jerusalem. In one basket there were fresh, just-ripened figs, but in the other the figs were spoiled and moldy—too rotten to eat.

3.verse: Then the Lord said to me, “What do you see, Jeremiah?” I replied, “Figs, some very good and some very bad.”

4.verse: Then the Lord said: “The good figs represent the exiles sent to Babylon. I have done it for their good.

5.verse: Then the Lord said: “The good figs represent the exiles sent to Babylon. I have done it for their good.

6.verse: I will see that they are well treated, and I will bring them back here again. I will help them and not hurt them; I will plant them and not pull them up.

7.verse: I will give them hearts that respond to me. They shall be my people and I will be their God, for they shall return to me with great joy.

8.verse: “But the rotten figs represent Zedekiah, king of Judah, his officials, and all the others of Jerusalem left here in this land; those too who live in Egypt. I will treat them like spoiled figs, too bad to use.

9.verse: I will make them repulsive to every nation of the earth, and they shall be mocked and taunted and cursed wherever I compel them to go.

10.verse: And I will send massacre and famine and disease among them until they are destroyed from the land of Israel, which I gave to them and to their fathers.”

1.verse: This message for all the people of Judah came from the Lord to Jeremiah during the fourth year of the reign of King Jehoiakim of Judah (son of Josiah). This was the year Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, began his reign.

2.verse: For the past twenty-three years, Jeremiah said, from the thirteenth year of the reign of Josiah (son of Amon) king of Judah, until now, God has been sending me his messages. I have faithfully passed them on to you, but you haven’t listened.

3.verse: For the past twenty-three years, Jeremiah said, from the thirteenth year of the reign of Josiah (son of Amon) king of Judah, until now, God has been sending me his messages. I have faithfully passed them on to you, but you haven’t listened.

4.verse: Again and again down through the years, God has sent you his prophets, but you have refused to hear.

5.verse: Each time the message was this: “Turn from the evil road you are traveling and from the evil things you are doing. Only then can you continue to live here in this land which the Lord gave to you and to your ancestors forever.

6.verse: Don’t anger me by worshiping idols; but if you are true to me, then I’ll not harm you.”

7.verse: But you won’t listen; you have gone ahead and made me furious with your idols. So you have brought upon yourselves all the evil that has come your way.

8.verse: And now the Lord God says: Because you have not listened to me, I will gather together all the armies of the north under Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon (I have appointed him as my deputy), and I will bring them all against this land and its people and against the other nations near you, and I will utterly destroy you and make you a byword of contempt forever.

9.verse: And now the Lord God says: Because you have not listened to me, I will gather together all the armies of the north under Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon (I have appointed him as my deputy), and I will bring them all against this land and its people and against the other nations near you, and I will utterly destroy you and make you a byword of contempt forever.

10.verse: I will take away your joy, your gladness, and your wedding feasts; your businesses shall fail, and all your homes shall lie in silent darkness.

11.verse: This entire land shall become a desolate wasteland; all the world will be shocked at the disaster that befalls you. Israel and her neighboring lands shall serve the king of Babylon for seventy years.

12.verse: Then, after these years of slavery are ended, I will punish the king of Babylon* and his people for their sins; I will make the land of Chaldea an everlasting waste.

13.verse: I will bring upon them all the terrors I have promised in this book—all the penalties announced by Jeremiah against the nations.

14.verse: For many nations and great kings shall enslave the Chaldeans, just as they enslaved my people; I will punish them in proportion to their treatment of my people.

15.verse: For the Lord God said to me: “Take from my hand this wine cup filled to the brim with my fury, and make all the nations to whom I send you drink from it.

16.verse: They shall drink from it and reel, crazed by the death blows I rain upon them.”

17.verse: So I took the cup of fury from the Lord and made all the nations drink from it—every nation God had sent me to;

18.verse: I went to Jerusalem and to the cities of Judah, and their kings and princes drank of the cup so that from that day until this they have been desolate, hated, and cursed, just as they are today.

19.verse: I went to Egypt, and Pharaoh, his servants, the princes, and the people—they too drank from that terrible cup, along with all the foreign population living in his land. So did all the kings of the land of Uz and the kings of the Philistine cities: Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and what remains of Ashdod,

20.verse: I went to Egypt, and Pharaoh, his servants, the princes, and the people—they too drank from that terrible cup, along with all the foreign population living in his land. So did all the kings of the land of Uz and the kings of the Philistine cities: Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and what remains of Ashdod,

21.verse: and I visited the nations of Edom, Moab, and Ammon;

22.verse: and all the kings of Tyre and Sidon, and the kings of the regions across the sea;

23.verse: Dedan, Tema, and Buz, and the other heathen there;

24.verse: and all the kings of Arabia and of the nomadic tribes of the desert;

25.verse: and all the kings of Zimri, Elam, and Media;

26.verse: and all the kings of the northern countries, far and near, one after the other; and all the kingdoms of the world. And finally, the king of Babylon himself drank from this cup of God’s wrath.

27.verse: Tell them, “The Lord of heaven’s armies, the God of Israel, says: Drink from this cup of my wrath until you are drunk and vomit and fall to rise no more, for I am sending terrible wars upon you.”

28.verse: And if they refuse to accept the cup, tell them, “The Lord of heaven’s armies says you must drink it! You cannot escape!

29.verse: I have begun to punish my own people, so should you go free? No, you shall not evade punishment. I will call for war against all the peoples of the earth.”

30.verse: Therefore prophesy against them. Tell them the Lord will shout against his own from his holy temple in heaven and against all those living on the earth. He will shout as the harvesters do who tread the juice from the grapes.

31.verse: That cry of judgment will reach the farthest ends of the earth, for the Lord has a case against all the nations—all mankind. He will slaughter all the wicked.

32.verse: See, declares the Lord Almighty, the punishment shall go from nation to nation—a great whirlwind of wrath shall rise against the farthest corners of the earth.

33.verse: On that day those the Lord has slain shall fill the earth from one end to the other. No one shall mourn for them nor gather up the bodies to bury them; they shall fertilize the earth.

34.verse: Weep and moan, O evil shepherds; let the leaders of mankind beat their heads upon the stones, for their time has come to be slaughtered and scattered; they shall fall like fragile women.

35.verse: And you will find no place to hide, no way to escape.

36.verse: Listen to the frantic cries of the shepherds and to the leaders shouting in despair, for the Lord has spoiled their pastures.

37.verse: People now living undisturbed will be cut down by the fierceness of the anger of the Lord.

38.verse: He has left his lair like a lion seeking prey; their land has been laid waste by warring armies—because of the fierce anger of the Lord.

1.verse: This message came to Jeremiah from the Lord during the first year of the reign of Jehoiakim (son of Josiah), king of Judah:

2.verse: Stand out in front of the Temple of the Lord and make an announcement to all the people who have come there to worship from many parts of Judah. Give them the entire message; don’t leave out one word of all I have for them to hear.

3.verse: For perhaps they will listen and turn from their evil ways, and then I can withhold all the punishment I am ready to pour out upon them because of their evil deeds.

4.verse: Tell them the Lord says: If you will not listen to me and obey the laws I have given you,

5.verse: and if you will not listen to my servants, the prophets—for I sent them again and again to warn you, but you would not listen to them—

6.verse: then I will destroy this Temple as I destroyed the Tabernacle at Shiloh, and I will make Jerusalem a curse word in every nation of the earth.

7.verse: When Jeremiah had finished his message, saying everything the Lord had told him to, the priests and false prophets and all the people in the Temple mobbed him, shouting, “Kill him! Kill him!

8.verse: When Jeremiah had finished his message, saying everything the Lord had told him to, the priests and false prophets and all the people in the Temple mobbed him, shouting, “Kill him! Kill him!

9.verse: What right do you have to say the Lord will destroy this Temple like the one at Shiloh?” they yelled. “What do you mean—Jerusalem destroyed and not one survivor?”

10.verse: When the high officials of Judah heard what was going on, they rushed over from the palace and sat down at the door of the Temple to hold court.

11.verse: Then the priests and the false prophets presented their accusations to the officials and the people. “This man should die!” they said. “You have heard with your own ears what a traitor he is, for he has prophesied against this city.”

12.verse: Then Jeremiah spoke in his defense. “The Lord sent me,” he said, “to prophesy against this Temple and this city. He gave me every word of all that I have spoken.

13.verse: But if you stop your sinning and begin obeying the Lord your God, he will cancel all the punishment he has announced against you.

14.verse: As for me, I am helpless and in your power—do with me as you think best.

15.verse: But there is one thing sure, if you kill me, you will be killing an innocent man, and the responsibility will lie upon you and upon this city and upon every person living in it; for it is absolutely true that the Lord sent me to speak every word that you have heard from me.”

16.verse: Then the officials and people said to the priests and false prophets, “This man does not deserve the death sentence, for he has spoken to us in the name of the Lord our God.”

17.verse: Then some of the wise old men stood and spoke to all the people standing around and said:

18.verse: “The decision is right; for back in the days when Micah of Moresheth prophesied in the days of King Hezekiah of Judah, he told the people that God said: ‘This hill shall be plowed like an open field and this city of Jerusalem razed into heaps of stone, and a forest shall grow at the top where the great Temple now stands!’

19.verse: But did King Hezekiah and the people kill him for saying this? No, they turned from their wickedness and worshiped the Lord and begged the Lord to have mercy upon them; and the Lord held back the terrible punishment he had pronounced against them. If we kill Jeremiah for giving us the messages of God, who knows what God will do to us!”

20.verse: Another true prophet of the Lord, Uriah (son of Shemaiah) from Kiriath-jearim, was also denouncing the city and the nation at the same time as Jeremiah was.

21.verse: But when King Jehoiakim and the army officers and officials heard what he was saying, the king sent to kill him. Uriah heard about it and fled to Egypt.

22.verse: Then King Jehoiakim sent Elnathan (son of Achbor) to Egypt along with several other men to capture Uriah.

23.verse: They took him prisoner and brought him back to King Jehoiakim, who butchered him with a sword and had him buried in an unmarked grave.

24.verse: But Ahikam (son of Shaphan), the royal secretary, stood with Jeremiah and persuaded the court not to turn him over to the mob to kill him.

1.verse: This message came to Jeremiah from the Lord at the beginning of the reign of Jehoiakim (son of Josiah), king of Judah:

2.verse: “Make a yoke and fasten it on your neck with leather thongs as you would strap a yoke on an ox.

3.verse: Then send messages to the kings of Edom, Moab, Ammon, Tyre, and Sidon, through their ambassadors in Jerusalem,

4.verse: saying, Tell your masters that the Lord, the God of Israel, sends you this message:

5.verse: “By my great power I have made the earth and all mankind and every animal; and I give these things of mine to anyone I want to.

6.verse: So now I have given all your countries to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, who is my deputy. And I have handed over to him all your cattle for his use.

7.verse: All the nations shall serve him and his son and his grandson until his time is up, and then many nations and great kings shall conquer Babylon and make him their slave.

8.verse: Submit to him and serve him—put your neck under Babylon’s yoke! I will punish any nation refusing to be his slave; I will send war, famine, and disease upon that nation until he has conquered it.

9.verse: “Do not listen to your false prophets, fortune-tellers, dreamers, mediums, and magicians who say the king of Babylon will not enslave you.

10.verse: For they are all liars, and if you follow their advice and refuse to submit to the king of Babylon, I will drive you out of your land and send you far away to perish.

11.verse: But the people of any nation submitting to the king of Babylon will be permitted to stay in their own country and farm the land as usual.”

12.verse: Jeremiah repeated all these prophecies to Zedekiah, king of Judah. “If you want to live, submit to the king of Babylon,” he said.

13.verse: “Why do you insist on dying—you and your people? Why should you choose war and famine and disease, which the Lord has promised to every nation that will not submit to Babylon’s king?

14.verse: Don’t listen to the false prophets who keep telling you the king of Babylon will not conquer you, for they are liars.

15.verse: I have not sent them, says the Lord, and they are telling you lies in my name. If you insist on heeding them, I must drive you from this land to die—you and all these ‘prophets’ too.”

16.verse: I spoke again and again to the priests and all the people and told them: “This is what the Lord says! Don’t listen to your prophets who are telling you that soon the gold dishes taken from the Temple will be returned from Babylon. It is all a lie.

17.verse: Don’t listen to them. Surrender to the king of Babylon and live, for otherwise this whole city will be destroyed.

18.verse: If they are really God’s prophets, then let them pray to the Lord Almighty that the gold dishes still here in the Temple, left from before, and that those in the palace of the king of Judah and in the palaces in Jerusalem will not be carried away with you to Babylon!

19.verse: “For the Lord Almighty says: The pillars of bronze standing before the Temple, the great bronze basin in the Temple court, the metal stands, and all the other ceremonial articles left here by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, when he exiled all the important people of Judah and Jerusalem to Babylon, along with Jeconiah (son of Jehoiakim), king of Judah,

20.verse: “For the Lord Almighty says: The pillars of bronze standing before the Temple, the great bronze basin in the Temple court, the metal stands, and all the other ceremonial articles left here by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, when he exiled all the important people of Judah and Jerusalem to Babylon, along with Jeconiah (son of Jehoiakim), king of Judah,

21.verse: “For the Lord Almighty says: The pillars of bronze standing before the Temple, the great bronze basin in the Temple court, the metal stands, and all the other ceremonial articles left here by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, when he exiled all the important people of Judah and Jerusalem to Babylon, along with Jeconiah (son of Jehoiakim), king of Judah,

22.verse: will all yet be carried away to Babylon and will stay there until I send for them. Then I will bring them all back to Jerusalem again.”

1.verse: On a December day in that same year—the fourth year of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah—Hananiah (son of Azzur), a false prophet from Gibeon, addressed me publicly in the Temple while all the priests and people listened. He said:

2.verse: “The Lord of Hosts, the God of Israel, declares: I have removed the yoke of the king of Babylon from your necks.

3.verse: Within two years I will bring back all the Temple treasures that Nebuchadnezzar carried off to Babylon,

4.verse: and I will bring back King Jeconiah, son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, and all the other captives exiled to Babylon, says the Lord. I will surely remove the yoke put on your necks by the king of Babylon.”

5.verse: Then Jeremiah said to Hananiah, in front of all the priests and people,

6.verse: “Amen! May your prophecies come true! I hope the Lord will do everything you say and bring back from Babylon the treasures of this Temple, with all our loved ones.

7.verse: But listen now to the solemn words I speak to you in the presence of all these people.

8.verse: The ancient prophets who preceded you and me spoke against many nations, always warning of war, famine, and plague.

9.verse: So a prophet who foretells peace has the burden of proof on him to prove that God has really sent him. Only when his message comes true can it be known that he really is from God.”

10.verse: Then Hananiah, the false prophet, took the yoke off Jeremiah’s neck and broke it.

11.verse: And Hananiah said again to the crowd that had gathered, “The Lord has promised that within two years he will release all the nations now in slavery to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon.” At that point Jeremiah walked out.

12.verse: Soon afterwards the Lord gave this message to Jeremiah:

13.verse: Go and tell Hananiah that the Lord says: You have broken a wooden yoke, but these people have yokes of iron on their necks.

14.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel, says: I have put a yoke of iron on the necks of all these nations, forcing them into slavery to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon. And nothing will change this decree, for I have even given him all your flocks and herds.

15.verse: Then Jeremiah said to Hananiah, the false prophet, “Listen, Hananiah, the Lord has not sent you, and the people are believing your lies.

16.verse: Therefore the Lord says you must die. This very year your life will end because you have rebelled against the Lord.”

17.verse: And sure enough, two months later Hananiah died.

1.verse: After Jeconiah the king, the queen mother, the court officials, the tribal officers, and craftsmen had been deported to Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar, Jeremiah wrote them a letter from Jerusalem, addressing it to the Jewish elders, priests, prophets, and to all the people.

2.verse: After Jeconiah the king, the queen mother, the court officials, the tribal officers, and craftsmen had been deported to Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar, Jeremiah wrote them a letter from Jerusalem, addressing it to the Jewish elders, priests, prophets, and to all the people.

3.verse: He sent the letter with Elasah (son of Shaphan) and Gemariah (son of Hilkiah) when they went to Babylon as King Zedekiah’s ambassadors to Nebuchadnezzar. And this is what the letter said:

4.verse: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, sends this message to all the captives he has exiled to Babylon from Jerusalem:

5.verse: Build homes and plan to stay; plant vineyards, for you will be there many years.

6.verse: Marry and have children, and then find mates for them and have many grandchildren. Multiply! Don’t dwindle away!

7.verse: And work for the peace and prosperity of Babylon. Pray for her, for if Babylon has peace, so will you.

8.verse: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: Don’t let the false prophets and mediums who are there among you fool you. Don’t listen to the dreams that they invent,

9.verse: for they prophesy lies in my name. I have not sent them, says the Lord.

10.verse: The truth is this: You will be in Babylon for seventy years. But then I will come and do for you all the good things I have promised and bring you home again.

11.verse: For I know the plans I have for you, says the Lord. They are plans for good and not for evil, to give you a future and a hope.

12.verse: In those days when you pray, I will listen.

13.verse: You will find me when you seek me, if you look for me in earnest.

14.verse: Yes, says the Lord, I will be found by you, and I will end your slavery and restore your fortunes; I will gather you out of the nations where I sent you and bring you back home again to your own land.

15.verse: But now, because you accept the false prophets among you and say the Lord has sent them,

16.verse: I will send war, famine, and plague upon the people left here in Jerusalem—on your relatives who were not exiled to Babylon, and on the king who sits on David’s throne—and make them like rotting figs, too bad to eat.

17.verse: I will send war, famine, and plague upon the people left here in Jerusalem—on your relatives who were not exiled to Babylon, and on the king who sits on David’s throne—and make them like rotting figs, too bad to eat.

18.verse: And I will scatter them around the world. And in every nation where I place them they will be cursed and hissed and mocked,

19.verse: for they refuse to listen to me though I spoke to them again and again through my prophets.

20.verse: Therefore listen to the word of God, all you Jewish captives over there in Babylon.

21.verse: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says this about your false prophets, Ahab (son of Kolaiah) and Zedekiah (son of Maaseiah), who are declaring lies to you in my name: Look, I am turning them over to Nebuchadnezzar to execute publicly.

22.verse: Their fate shall become proverbial of all evil, so that whenever anyone wants to curse someone he will say, “The Lord make you like Zedekiah and Ahab whom the king of Babylon burned alive!”

23.verse: For these men have done a terrible thing among my people. They have committed adultery with their neighbors’ wives and have lied in my name. I know, for I have seen everything they do, says the Lord.

24.verse: And say this to Shemaiah the dreamer:

25.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel, says: You have written a letter to Zephaniah (son of Maaseiah) the priest, and sent copies to all the other priests and to everyone in Jerusalem.

26.verse: And in this letter you have said to Zephaniah, “The Lord has appointed you to replace Jehoiada as priest in Jerusalem. And it is your responsibility to arrest any madman who claims to be a prophet and to put him in the stocks and collar.

27.verse: Why haven’t you done something about this false prophet Jeremiah of Anathoth?

28.verse: For he has written to us here in Babylon saying that our captivity will be long; that we should build permanent homes and plan to stay many years; that we should plant fruit trees, for we will be here to eat the fruit from them for a long time to come.”

29.verse: Zephaniah took the letter over to Jeremiah and read it to him!

30.verse: Then the Lord gave this message to Jeremiah:

31.verse: Send an open letter to all the exiles in Babylon and tell them this: The Lord says that because Shemaiah the Nehelamite has “prophesied” to you when I didn’t send him and has fooled you into believing his lies,

32.verse: I will punish him and his family. None of his descendants shall see the good I have waiting for my people, for he has taught you to rebel against the Lord.

1.verse: This is another of the Lord’s messages to Jeremiah:

2.verse: The Lord God of Israel says: Write down for the record all that I have said to you.

3.verse: For the time is coming when I will restore the fortunes of my people, Israel and Judah, and I will bring them home to this land that I gave to their fathers; they shall possess it and live here again.

4.verse: And write this also concerning Israel and Judah:

5.verse: “Where shall we find peace?” they cry. “There is only fear and trembling.

6.verse: Do men give birth? Then why do they stand there, ashen-faced, hands pressed against their sides like women in labor?”

7.verse: Alas, in all history when has there ever been a time of terror such as in that coming day? It is a time of trouble for my people—for Jacob—such as they have never known before. Yet God will rescue them!

8.verse: For on that day, says the Lord Almighty, I will break the yoke from their necks and snap their chains, and foreigners shall no longer be their masters!

9.verse: For they shall serve the Lord their God, and David their King, whom I will raise up for them, says the Lord.

10.verse: So don’t be afraid, O Jacob my servant; don’t be dismayed, O Israel; for I will bring you home again from distant lands, and your children from their exile. They shall have rest and quiet in their own land, and no one shall make them afraid.

11.verse: For I am with you and I will save you, says the Lord. Even if I utterly destroy the nations where I scatter you, I will not exterminate you; I will punish you, yes—you will not go unpunished.

12.verse: For your sin is an incurable bruise, a terrible wound.

13.verse: There is no one to help you or to bind up your wound, and no medicine does any good.

14.verse: All your lovers have left you and don’t care anything about you anymore; for I have wounded you cruelly, as though I were your enemy; mercilessly, as though I were an implacable foe; for your sins are so many, your guilt is so great.

15.verse: Why do you protest your punishment? Your sin is so scandalous that your sorrow should never end! It is because your guilt is great that I have had to punish you so much.

16.verse: But in that coming day, all who are destroying you shall be destroyed, and all your enemies shall be slaves. Those who rob you shall be robbed; and those attacking you shall be attacked.

17.verse: I will give you back your health again and heal your wounds. Now you are called “The Outcast” and “Jerusalem, the Place Nobody Wants.”

18.verse: But, says the Lord, when I bring you home again from your captivity and restore your fortunes, Jerusalem will be rebuilt upon her ruins; the palace will be reconstructed as it was before.

19.verse: The cities will be filled with joy and great thanksgiving, and I will multiply my people and make of them a great and honored nation.

20.verse: Their children shall prosper as in David’s reign; their nations shall be established before me, and I will punish anyone who hurts them.

21.verse: They will have their own ruler again. He will not be a foreigner. And I will invite him to be a priest at my altars, and he shall approach me, for who would dare to come unless invited.

22.verse: And you shall be my people, and I will be your God.

23.verse: Suddenly the devastating whirlwind of the Lord roars with fury; it shall burst upon the heads of the wicked.

24.verse: The Lord will not call off the fierceness of his wrath until it has finished all the terrible destruction he has planned. Later on you will understand what I am telling you.

1.verse: At that time, says the Lord, all the families of Israel shall recognize me as the Lord; they shall act like my people.

2.verse: I will care for them as I did those who escaped from Egypt, to whom I showed my mercies in the wilderness, when Israel sought for rest.

3.verse: For long ago the Lord had said to Israel: I have loved you, O my people, with an everlasting love; with loving-kindness I have drawn you to me.

4.verse: I will rebuild your nation, O virgin of Israel. You will again be happy and dance merrily with the timbrels.

5.verse: Again you will plant your vineyards upon the mountains of Samaria and eat from your own gardens there.

6.verse: The day shall come when watchmen on the hills of Ephraim will call out and say, “Arise, and let us go up to Zion to the Lord our God.”

7.verse: For the Lord says: Sing with joy for all that I will do for Israel, the greatest of the nations! Shout out with praise and joy: “The Lord has saved his people, the remnant of Israel.”

8.verse: For I will bring them from the north and from earth’s farthest ends, not forgetting their blind and lame, young mothers with their little ones, those ready to give birth. It will be a great company who comes.

9.verse: Tears of joy shall stream down their faces, and I will lead them home with great care. They shall walk beside the quiet streams and not stumble. For I am a Father to Israel, and Ephraim is my oldest child.

10.verse: Listen to this message from the Lord, you nations of the world, and publish it abroad: The Lord who scattered his people will gather them back together again and watch over them as a shepherd does his flock.

11.verse: He will save Israel from those who are too strong for them!

12.verse: They shall come home and sing songs of joy upon the hills of Zion and shall be radiant over the goodness of the Lord—the good crops, the wheat, the wine, and the oil, and the healthy flocks and herds. Their life shall be like a watered garden, and all their sorrows shall be gone.

13.verse: The young girls will dance for joy, and menfolk—old and young—will take their part in all the fun; for I will turn their mourning into joy, and I will comfort them and make them rejoice, for their captivity with all its sorrows will be behind them.

14.verse: I will feast the priests with the abundance of offerings brought to them at the Temple; I will satisfy my people with my bounty, says the Lord.

15.verse: The Lord spoke to me again, saying: In Ramah there is bitter weeping—Rachel is weeping for her children and cannot be comforted, for they are gone.

16.verse: But the Lord says: Don’t cry any longer, for I have heard your prayers and you will see them again; they will come back to you from the distant land of the enemy.

17.verse: There is hope for your future, says the Lord, and your children will come again to their own land.

18.verse: I have heard Ephraim’s groans: “You have punished me greatly; but I needed it all, as a calf must be trained for the yoke. Turn me again to you and restore me, for you alone are the Lord, my God.

19.verse: I turned away from God, but I was sorry afterwards. I kicked myself for my stupidity. I was thoroughly ashamed of all I did in younger days.”

20.verse: And the Lord replies: Ephraim is still my son, my darling child. I had to punish him, but I still love him. I long for him and surely will have mercy on him.

21.verse: As you travel into exile, set up road signs pointing back to Israel. Mark your pathway well. For you shall return again, O virgin Israel, to your cities here.

22.verse: How long will you vacillate, O wayward daughter? For the Lord will cause something new and different to happen—Israel will search for God.

23.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel, says: When I bring them back again, they shall say in Judah and her cities, “The Lord bless you, O center of righteousness, O holy hill!”

24.verse: And city dwellers and farmers and shepherds alike shall live together in peace and happiness.

25.verse: For I have given rest to the weary and joy to all the sorrowing.

26.verse: (Then Jeremiah wakened. “Such sleep is very sweet!” he said.)

27.verse: The Lord says: The time will come when I will greatly increase the population and multiply the number of cattle here in Israel.

28.verse: In the past I painstakingly destroyed the nation, but now I will carefully build it up.

29.verse: The people shall no longer quote this proverb—“Children pay for their fathers’ sins.”

30.verse: For everyone shall die for his own sins—the person eating sour grapes is the one whose teeth are set on edge.

31.verse: The day will come, says the Lord, when I will make a new contract with the people of Israel and Judah.

32.verse: It won’t be like the one I made with their fathers when I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt—a contract they broke, forcing me to reject them, says the Lord.

33.verse: But this is the new contract I will make with them: I will inscribe my laws upon their hearts, so that they shall want to honor me;* then they shall truly be my people and I will be their God.

34.verse: At that time it will no longer be necessary to admonish one another to know the Lord. For everyone, both great and small, shall really know me then, says the Lord, and I will forgive and forget their sins.

35.verse: The Lord who gives us sunlight in the daytime and the moon and stars to light the night, and who stirs the sea to make the roaring waves—his name is Lord Almighty—says this:

36.verse: I am as likely to reject my people Israel as I am to do away with these laws of nature!

37.verse: Not until the heavens can be measured and the foundations of the earth explored, will I consider casting them away forever for their sins!

38.verse: For the time is coming, says the Lord, when all Jerusalem shall be rebuilt for the Lord, from the tower of Hananel at the northeast corner, to the Corner Gate at the northwest;* and from the hill of Gareb at the southwest,* across to Goah on the southeast.*

39.verse: For the time is coming, says the Lord, when all Jerusalem shall be rebuilt for the Lord, from the tower of Hananel at the northeast corner, to the Corner Gate at the northwest;* and from the hill of Gareb at the southwest,* across to Goah on the southeast.*

40.verse: And the entire city, including the graveyard and ash dump in the valley, and all the fields out to the brook of Kidron, and from there to the Horse Gate on the east side of the city, all shall be holy to the Lord; it shall never again be captured or destroyed.

1.verse: The following message came to Jeremiah from the Lord in the tenth year of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah (which was the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar’s reign).

2.verse: At this time Jeremiah was imprisoned in the dungeon beneath the palace, while the Babylonian army was besieging Jerusalem.

3.verse: King Zedekiah had put him there for continuing to prophesy that the city would be conquered by the king of Babylon,

4.verse: and that King Zedekiah would be caught and taken as a prisoner before the king of Babylon for trial and sentencing.

5.verse: “He shall take you to Babylon and imprison you there for many years until you die. Why fight the facts? You can’t win! Surrender now!” Jeremiah had told him again and again.

6.verse: Then this message from the Lord came to Jeremiah: Your cousin Hanamel (son of Shallum) will soon arrive to ask you to buy the farm he owns in Anathoth, for by law you have a chance to buy before it is offered to anyone else.

7.verse: Then this message from the Lord came to Jeremiah: Your cousin Hanamel (son of Shallum) will soon arrive to ask you to buy the farm he owns in Anathoth, for by law you have a chance to buy before it is offered to anyone else.

8.verse: So Hanamel came, as the Lord had said he would, and visited me in the prison. “Buy my field in Anathoth, in the land of Benjamin,” he said, “for the law gives you the first right to purchase it.” Then I knew for sure that the message I had heard was really from the Lord.

9.verse: So I bought the field, paying Hanamel seventeen pieces of silver.

10.verse: I signed and sealed the deed of purchase before witnesses, weighed out the silver, and paid him.

11.verse: Then I took the sealed deed containing the terms and conditions and also the unsealed copy,

12.verse: and publicly, in the presence of my cousin Hanamel and the witnesses who had signed the deed, and as the prison guards watched, I handed the papers to Baruch (son of Neriah, who was the son of Mahseiah).

13.verse: And I said to him as they all listened:

14.verse: “The Lord, God of Israel, says: Take both this sealed deed and the copy and put them into a pottery jar to preserve them for a long time.

15.verse: For the Lord, God of Israel, says: In the future these papers will be valuable. Someday people will again own property here in this country and will be buying and selling houses and vineyards and fields.”

16.verse: Then after I had given the papers to Baruch I prayed:

17.verse: “O Lord God! You have made the heavens and earth by your great power; nothing is too hard for you!

18.verse: You are loving and kind to thousands, yet children suffer for their fathers’ sins; you are the great and mighty God, the Lord Almighty.

19.verse: You have all wisdom and do great and mighty miracles; for your eyes are open to all the ways of men, and you reward everyone according to his life and deeds.

20.verse: You have done incredible things in the land of Egypt—things still remembered to this day. And you have continued to do great miracles in Israel and all around the world. You have made your name very great, as it is today.

21.verse: “You brought Israel out of Egypt with mighty miracles and great power and terror.

22.verse: You gave Israel this land that you promised their fathers long ago—a wonderful land that ‘flows with milk and honey.’

23.verse: Our fathers came and conquered it and lived in it, but they refused to obey you or to follow your laws; they have hardly done one thing you told them to. That is why you have sent all this terrible evil upon them.

24.verse: See how the siege mounds have been built against the city walls, and the Babylonians shall conquer the city by sword, famine, and disease. Everything has happened just as you said—as you determined it should!

25.verse: And yet you say to buy the field—paying good money for it before these witnesses—even though the city will belong to our enemies.”

26.verse: Then this message came to Jeremiah:

27.verse: I am the Lord, the God of all mankind; is there anything too hard for me?

28.verse: Yes, I will give this city to the Babylonians and to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon; he shall conquer it.

29.verse: And the Babylonians outside the walls shall come in and set fire to the city and burn down all these houses, where the roofs have been used to offer incense to Baal and to pour out libations to other gods, causing my fury to rise!

30.verse: For Israel and Judah have done nothing but wrong since their earliest days; they have infuriated me with all their evil deeds.

31.verse: From the time this city was built until now, it has done nothing but anger me; so I am determined to be rid of it.

32.verse: The sins of Israel and Judah—the sins of the people, of their kings, officers, priests, and prophets—stir me up.

33.verse: They have turned their backs upon me and refused to return; day after day, year after year, I taught them right from wrong, but they would not listen or obey.

34.verse: They have even defiled my own Temple by worshiping their abominable idols there.

35.verse: And they have built high altars to Baal in the valley of Hinnom. There they have burnt their children as sacrifices to Molech—something I never commanded and cannot imagine suggesting. What an incredible evil, causing Judah to sin so greatly!

36.verse: Now therefore the Lord God of Israel says concerning this city that it will fall to the king of Babylon through warfare, famine, and disease,

37.verse: but I will bring my people back again from all the countries where in my fury I will scatter them. I will bring them back to this very city and make them live in peace and safety.

38.verse: And they shall be my people, and I will be their God.

39.verse: And I will give them one heart and mind to worship me forever, for their own good and for the good of all their descendants.

40.verse: And I will make an everlasting covenant with them, promising never again to desert them but only to do them good. I will put a desire into their hearts to worship me, and they shall never leave me.

41.verse: I will rejoice to do them good and will replant them in this land with great joy.

42.verse: Just as I have sent all these terrors and evils upon them, so will I do all the good I have promised them.

43.verse: Fields will again be bought and sold in this land now ravaged by the Babylonians, where men and animals alike have disappeared.

44.verse: Yes, fields shall once again be bought and sold—deeds signed and sealed and witnessed—in the country of Benjamin and here in Jerusalem, in the cities of Judah and in the hill country, in the Philistine Plain and in the Negeb too, for some day I will restore prosperity to them.

1.verse: While Jeremiah was still in jail, the Lord sent him this second message:

2.verse: The Lord, the Maker of heaven and earth—Jehovah is his name—says this:

3.verse: Ask me and I will tell you some remarkable secrets about what is going to happen here.

4.verse: For though you have torn down the houses of this city, and the king’s palace too, for materials to strengthen the walls against the siege weapons of the enemy,

5.verse: yet the Babylonians will enter, and the men of this city are already as good as dead, for I have determined to destroy them in my furious anger. I have abandoned them because of all their wickedness, and I will not pity them when they cry for help.

6.verse: Nevertheless the time will come when I will heal Jerusalem’s damage and give her prosperity and peace.

7.verse: I will rebuild the cities of both Judah and Israel and restore their fortunes.

8.verse: And I will cleanse away all their sins against me and pardon them.

9.verse: Then this city will be an honor to me, and it will give me joy and be a source of praise and glory to me before all the nations of the earth! The people of the world will see the good I do for my people and will tremble with awe!

10.verse: The Lord declares that the happy voices of bridegrooms and of brides and the joyous song of those bringing thanksgiving offerings to the Lord will be heard again in this doomed land. The people will sing: “Praise the Lord! For he is good and his mercy endures forever!” For I will make this land happier and more prosperous than it has ever been before.

11.verse: The Lord declares that the happy voices of bridegrooms and of brides and the joyous song of those bringing thanksgiving offerings to the Lord will be heard again in this doomed land. The people will sing: “Praise the Lord! For he is good and his mercy endures forever!” For I will make this land happier and more prosperous than it has ever been before.

12.verse: This land—though every man and animal and city is doomed—will once more see shepherds leading sheep and lambs.

13.verse: Once again their flocks will prosper in the mountain villages and in the cities east of the Philistine Plain, in all the cities of the Negeb, in the land of Benjamin, in the vicinity of Jerusalem, and in all the cities of Judah.

14.verse: Yes, the day will come, says the Lord, when I will do for Israel and Judah all the good I promised them.

15.verse: At that time I will bring to the throne the true Son of David, and he shall rule justly.

16.verse: In that day the people of Judah and Jerusalem shall live in safety and their motto will be, “The Lord is our righteousness!”

17.verse: For the Lord declares that from then on, David shall forever have an heir sitting on the throne of Israel.

18.verse: And there shall always be Levites to offer burnt offerings and meal offerings and sacrifices to the Lord.

19.verse: Then this message came to Jeremiah from the Lord:

20.verse: If you can break my covenant with the day and with the night so that day and night don’t come on their usual schedule, only then will my covenant with David, my servant, be broken so that he shall not have a son to reign upon his throne; and my covenant with the Levite priests, my ministers, is noncancelable.

21.verse: If you can break my covenant with the day and with the night so that day and night don’t come on their usual schedule, only then will my covenant with David, my servant, be broken so that he shall not have a son to reign upon his throne; and my covenant with the Levite priests, my ministers, is noncancelable.

22.verse: And as the stars cannot be counted nor the sand upon the seashores measured, so the descendants of David my servant and the line of the Levites who minister to me will be multiplied.

23.verse: The Lord spoke to Jeremiah again and said:

24.verse: Have you heard what people are saying?—that the Lord chose Judah and Israel and then abandoned them! They are sneering and saying that Israel isn’t worthy to be counted as a nation.

25.verse: But this is the Lord’s reply: I would no more reject my people than I would change my laws of night and day, of earth and sky. I will never abandon the Jews, or David my servant, or change the plan that his child will someday rule these descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Instead I will restore their prosperity and have mercy on them.

26.verse: But this is the Lord’s reply: I would no more reject my people than I would change my laws of night and day, of earth and sky. I will never abandon the Jews, or David my servant, or change the plan that his child will someday rule these descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Instead I will restore their prosperity and have mercy on them.

1.verse: This is the message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord when Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and all his armies from all the kingdoms he ruled, came and fought against Jerusalem and the cities of Judah:

2.verse: Go tell Zedekiah, king of Judah, that the Lord says this: I will give this city to the king of Babylon and he shall burn it.

3.verse: You shall not escape; you shall be captured and taken before the king of Babylon; he shall pronounce sentence against you and you shall be exiled to Babylon.

4.verse: But listen to this, O Zedekiah, king of Judah: God says you won’t be killed in war and carnage

5.verse: but that you will die quietly among your people, and they will burn incense in your memory, just as they did for your fathers. They will weep for you and say, “Alas, our king is dead!” This I have decreed, says the Lord.

6.verse: So Jeremiah delivered the message to King Zedekiah.

7.verse: At this time the Babylonian army was besieging Jerusalem, Lachish, and Azekah—the only walled cities of Judah still standing.

8.verse: This is the message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord after King Zedekiah of Judah had freed all the slaves in Jerusalem—

9.verse: (for King Zedekiah had ordered everyone to free his Hebrew slaves, both men and women. He had said that no Jew should be the master of another Jew for all were brothers.

10.verse: The princes and all the people had obeyed the king’s command and freed their slaves, but the action was only temporary.

11.verse: They changed their minds and made their servants slaves again.

12.verse: That is why the Lord gave the following message to Jerusalem.)

13.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel, says: I made a covenant with your fathers long ago when I brought them from their slavery in Egypt.

14.verse: I told them that every Hebrew slave must be freed after serving six years. But this was not done.

15.verse: Recently you began doing what was right, as I commanded you, and freed your slaves. You had solemnly promised me in my Temple that you would do it.

16.verse: But now you refuse and have defiled my name by shrugging off your oath and have made them slaves again.

17.verse: Therefore, says the Lord, because you will not listen to me and release them, I will release you to the power of death by war and famine and disease. And I will scatter you over all the world as exiles.

18.verse: Because you have refused the terms of our contract, I will cut you apart just as you cut apart the calf when you walked between its halves to solemnize your vows. Yes, I will butcher you, whether you are princes, court officials, priests, or people—for you have broken your oath.

19.verse: Because you have refused the terms of our contract, I will cut you apart just as you cut apart the calf when you walked between its halves to solemnize your vows. Yes, I will butcher you, whether you are princes, court officials, priests, or people—for you have broken your oath.

20.verse: I will give you to your enemies, and they shall kill you. I will feed your dead bodies to the vultures and wild animals.

21.verse: And I will surrender Zedekiah, king of Judah, and his officials to the army of the king of Babylon, though he has departed from the city for a little while.

22.verse: I will summon the Babylonian armies back again, and they will fight against it and capture this city and burn it. And I will see to it that the cities of Judah are completely destroyed and left desolate without a living soul.

1.verse: This is the message the Lord gave Jeremiah when Jehoiakim (son of Josiah) was the king of Judah:

2.verse: Go to the settlement where the families of the Rechabites live and invite them to the Temple. Take them into one of the inner rooms and offer them a drink of wine.

3.verse: So I went over to see Jaazaniah (son of Jeremiah, who was the son of Habazziniah) and brought him and all his brothers and sons—representing all the Rechab families—

4.verse: to the Temple, into the room assigned for the use of the sons of Hanan the prophet (the son of Igdaliah). This room was located next to the one used by the palace official, directly above the room of Maaseiah (son of Shallum), who was the Temple doorman.

5.verse: I set cups and jugs of wine before them and invited them to have a drink,

6.verse: but they refused. “No,” they said. “We don’t drink, for Jonadab our father (son of Rechab) commanded that none of us should ever drink, neither we nor our children forever.

7.verse: He also told us not to build houses or plant crops or vineyards and not to own farms, but always to live in tents; and that if we obeyed, we would live long, good lives in our own land.

8.verse: And we have obeyed him in all these things. We have never had a drink of wine since then, nor have our wives or our sons or daughters either.

9.verse: We haven’t built houses or owned farms or planted crops.

10.verse: We have lived in tents and have fully obeyed everything that Jonadab our father commanded us.

11.verse: But when Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, arrived in this country, we were afraid and decided to move to Jerusalem. That’s why we are here.”

12.verse: Then the Lord gave this message to Jeremiah:

13.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel, says: Go and say to Judah and Jerusalem, Won’t you learn a lesson from the families of Rechab?

14.verse: They don’t drink because their father told them not to. But I have spoken to you again and again, and you won’t listen or obey.

15.verse: I have sent you prophet after prophet to tell you to turn back from your wicked ways and to stop worshiping other gods, and that if you obeyed, then I would let you live in peace here in the land I gave to you and your fathers. But you wouldn’t listen or obey.

16.verse: The families of Rechab have obeyed their father completely, but you have refused to listen to me.

17.verse: Therefore, the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: Because you refuse to listen or answer when I call, I will send upon Judah and Jerusalem all the evil I have ever threatened.

18.verse: Then Jeremiah turned to the Rechabites and said: “The Lord, the God of Israel, says that because you have obeyed your father in every respect, he shall always have descendants who will worship me.”

19.verse: Then Jeremiah turned to the Rechabites and said: “The Lord, the God of Israel, says that because you have obeyed your father in every respect, he shall always have descendants who will worship me.”

1.verse: In the fourth year of the reign of King Jehoiakim of Judah (son of Josiah) the Lord gave this message to Jeremiah:

2.verse: “Get a scroll and write down all my messages against Israel, Judah, and the other nations. Begin with the first message back in the days of Josiah, and write down every one of them.

3.verse: Perhaps when the people of Judah see in writing all the terrible things I will do to them, they will repent. And then I can forgive them.”

4.verse: So Jeremiah sent for Baruch (son of Neriah), and as Jeremiah dictated, Baruch wrote down all the prophecies.

5.verse: When all was finished, Jeremiah said to Baruch, “Since I am a prisoner here,

6.verse: you read the scroll in the Temple on the next day of fasting, for on that day people will be there from all over Judah.

7.verse: Perhaps even yet they will turn from their evil ways and ask the Lord to forgive them before it is too late, even though these curses of God have been pronounced upon them.”

8.verse: Baruch did as Jeremiah told him to and read all these messages to the people at the Temple.

9.verse: This occurred on the day of fasting held in December of the fifth year of the reign of King Jehoiakim (son of Josiah). People came from all over Judah to attend the services at the Temple that day.

10.verse: Baruch went to the office of Gemariah the scribe (son of Shaphan) to read the scroll. (This room was just off the upper assembly hall of the Temple, near the door of the New Gate.)

11.verse: When Micaiah (son of Gemariah, son of Shaphan) heard the messages from God,

12.verse: he went down to the palace to the conference room where the administrative officials were meeting. Elishama (the scribe) was there, as well as Delaiah (son of Shemaiah), Elnathan (son of Achbor), Gemariah (son of Shaphan), Zedekiah (son of Hananiah), and all the others with similar responsibilities.

13.verse: When Micaiah told them about the messages Baruch was reading to the people,

14.verse: the officials sent Jehudi (son of Nethaniah, son of Shelemiah, son of Cushi) to ask Baruch to come and read the messages to them too, and Baruch did.

15.verse: the officials sent Jehudi (son of Nethaniah, son of Shelemiah, son of Cushi) to ask Baruch to come and read the messages to them too, and Baruch did.

16.verse: By the time he finished they were badly frightened. “We must tell the king,” they said.

17.verse: “But first, tell us how you got these messages. Did Jeremiah himself dictate them to you?”

18.verse: So Baruch explained that Jeremiah had dictated them to him word by word, and he had written them down in ink upon the scroll.

19.verse: “You and Jeremiah both hide,” the officials said to Baruch. “Don’t tell a soul where you are!”

20.verse: Then the officials hid the scroll in the room of Elishama the scribe and went to tell the king.

21.verse: The king sent Jehudi to get the scroll. Jehudi brought it from Elishama the scribe and read it to the king as all his officials stood by.

22.verse: The king was in a winterized part of the palace at the time, sitting in front of a fireplace, for it was December and cold.

23.verse: And whenever Jehudi finished reading three or four columns, the king would take his knife, slit off the section, and throw it into the fire, until the whole scroll was destroyed.

24.verse: And no one protested except Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah. They pled with the king not to burn the scroll, but he wouldn’t listen to them. Not another of the king’s officials showed any signs of fear or anger at what he had done.

25.verse: And no one protested except Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah. They pled with the king not to burn the scroll, but he wouldn’t listen to them. Not another of the king’s officials showed any signs of fear or anger at what he had done.

26.verse: Then the king commanded Jerahmeel (a member of the royal family) and Seraiah (son of Azriel) and Shelemiah (son of Abdeel) to arrest Baruch and Jeremiah. But the Lord hid them!

27.verse: After the king had burned the scroll, the Lord said to Jeremiah:

28.verse: Get another scroll and write everything again just as you did before,

29.verse: and say this to the king: “This is what the Lord says! You burned the scroll because it said the king of Babylon would destroy this country and everything in it.

30.verse: And now the Lord adds this concerning you, Jehoiakim, king of Judah: He shall have no one to sit upon the throne of David. His dead body shall be thrown out to the hot sun and frosty nights,

31.verse: and I will punish him and his family and his officials because of their sins. I will pour out upon them all the evil I promised—upon them and upon all the people of Judah and Jerusalem, for they wouldn’t listen to my warnings.”

32.verse: Then Jeremiah took another scroll and dictated again to Baruch all he had written before, only this time the Lord added a lot more!

1.verse: Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, did not appoint Coniah (King Jehoiakim’s son) to be the new king of Judah. Instead he chose Zedekiah (son of Josiah).

2.verse: But neither King Zedekiah nor his officials nor the people who were left in the land listened to what the Lord said through Jeremiah.

3.verse: Nevertheless, King Zedekiah sent Jehucal (son of Shelemiah) and Zephaniah the priest (son of Maaseiah) to ask Jeremiah to pray for them.

4.verse: (Jeremiah had not been imprisoned yet, so he could come and go as he pleased.)

5.verse: When the army of Pharaoh Hophra of Egypt appeared at the southern border of Judah to relieve the besieged city of Jerusalem, the Babylonian army withdrew from Jerusalem to fight the Egyptians.

6.verse: Then the Lord sent this message to Jeremiah:

7.verse: “The Lord, the God of Israel, says: Tell the king of Judah, who sent you to ask me what is going to happen, that Pharaoh’s army, though it came here to help you, is about to return in flight to Egypt! The Babylonians shall defeat them and send them scurrying home.

8.verse: These Babylonians shall capture this city and burn it to the ground.

9.verse: Don’t fool yourselves that the Babylonians are gone for good. They aren’t!

10.verse: Even if you destroyed the entire Babylonian army until there was only a handful of survivors and they lay wounded in their tents, yet they would stagger out and defeat you and put this city to the torch!”

11.verse: When the Babylonian army set out from Jerusalem to engage Pharaoh’s army in battle,

12.verse: Jeremiah started to leave the city to go to the land of Benjamin, to see the property he had bought.

13.verse: But as he was walking through the Benjamin Gate, a sentry arrested him as a traitor, claiming he was defecting to the Babylonians. The guard making the arrest was Irijah (son of Shelemiah, grandson of Hananiah).

14.verse: “That’s not true,” Jeremiah said. “I have no intention whatever of doing any such thing!” But Irijah wouldn’t listen; he took Jeremiah before the city officials.

15.verse: They were incensed with Jeremiah and had him flogged and put into the dungeon under the house of Jonathan the scribe, which had been converted into a prison. Jeremiah was kept there for several days,

16.verse: They were incensed with Jeremiah and had him flogged and put into the dungeon under the house of Jonathan the scribe, which had been converted into a prison. Jeremiah was kept there for several days,

17.verse: but eventually King Zedekiah sent for him to come to the palace secretly. The king asked him if there was any recent message from the Lord. “Yes,” said Jeremiah, “there is! You shall be defeated by the king of Babylon!”

18.verse: Then Jeremiah broached the subject of his imprisonment. “What have I ever done to deserve this?” he asked the king. “What crime have I committed? Tell me what I have done against you or your officials or the people?

19.verse: Where are those prophets now who told you that the king of Babylon would not come?

20.verse: Listen, O my lord the king: I beg you, don’t send me back to that dungeon, for I’ll die there.”

21.verse: Then King Zedekiah commanded that Jeremiah not be returned to the dungeon but be placed in the palace prison instead, and that he be given a small loaf of fresh bread every day as long as there was any left in the city. So Jeremiah was kept in the palace prison.

1.verse: But when Shephatiah (son of Mattan) and Gedaliah (son of Pashhur) and Jucal (son of Shelemiah) and Pashhur (son of Malchiah) heard what Jeremiah had been telling the people—

2.verse: that everyone remaining in Jerusalem would die by sword, starvation, or disease, but anyone surrendering to the Babylonians would live,

3.verse: and that the city of Jerusalem would surely be captured by the king of Babylon—

4.verse: they went to the king and said: “Sir, this fellow must die. That kind of talk will undermine the morale of the few soldiers we have left, and of all the people too. This man is a traitor.”

5.verse: So King Zedekiah agreed. “All right,” he said. “Do as you like—I can’t stop you.”

6.verse: They took Jeremiah from his cell and lowered him by ropes into an empty cistern in the prison yard. (It belonged to Malchiah, a member of the royal family.) There was no water in it, but there was a thick layer of mire at the bottom, and Jeremiah sank down into it.

7.verse: When Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, an important palace official, heard that Jeremiah was in the cistern,

8.verse: he rushed out to the Gate of Benjamin where the king was holding court.

9.verse: “My lord the king,” he said, “these men have done a very evil thing in putting Jeremiah into the cistern. He will die of hunger, for almost all the bread in the city is gone.”

10.verse: Then the king commanded Ebed-melech to take thirty men with him and pull Jeremiah out before he died.

11.verse: So Ebed-melech took thirty men and went to a palace depot for discarded supplies where used clothing was kept. There he found some old rags and discarded garments which he took to the cistern and lowered to Jeremiah on a rope.

12.verse: Ebed-melech called down to Jeremiah, “Use these rags under your armpits to protect you from the ropes.” Then, when Jeremiah was ready,

13.verse: they pulled him out and returned him to the palace prison, where he remained.

14.verse: One day King Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah to meet him at the side entrance of the Temple. “I want to ask you something,” the king said, “and don’t try to hide the truth.”

15.verse: Jeremiah said, “If I tell you the truth, you will kill me. And you won’t listen to me anyway.”

16.verse: So King Zedekiah swore before Almighty God his Creator that he would not kill Jeremiah or give him to the men who were after his life.

17.verse: Then Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “The Almighty Lord, the God of Israel, says: If you will surrender to Babylon, you and your family shall live and the city will not be burned.
