18.verse: If you refuse to surrender, this city shall be set afire by the Babylonian army and you will not escape.”

19.verse: “But I am afraid to surrender,” the king said, “for the Babylonians will hand me over to the Jews who have defected to them, and who knows what they will do to me?”

20.verse: Jeremiah replied, “You won’t get into their hands if only you will obey the Lord; your life will be spared, and all will go well for you.

21.verse: But if you refuse to surrender, the Lord has said that all the women left in your palace will be brought out and given to the officers of the Babylonian army; and these women will taunt you with bitterness. ‘Fine friends you have,’ they’ll say, ‘those Egyptians. They have betrayed you and left you to your fate!’

22.verse: But if you refuse to surrender, the Lord has said that all the women left in your palace will be brought out and given to the officers of the Babylonian army; and these women will taunt you with bitterness. ‘Fine friends you have,’ they’ll say, ‘those Egyptians. They have betrayed you and left you to your fate!’

23.verse: All your wives and children will be led out to the Babylonians, and you will not escape. You will be seized by the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned.”

24.verse: Then Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “On pain of death, don’t tell anyone you told me this!

25.verse: And if my officials hear that I talked with you and they threaten you with death unless you tell them what we discussed,

26.verse: just say that you begged me not to send you back to the dungeon in Jonathan’s house, for you would die there.”

27.verse: And sure enough, it wasn’t long before all the city officials came to Jeremiah and asked him why the king had called for him. So he said what the king had told him to, and they left without finding out the truth, for the conversation had not been overheard by anyone.

28.verse: And Jeremiah remained confined to the prison yard until the day Jerusalem was captured.

1.verse: It was in January of the ninth year of the reign of King Zedekiah of Judah that King Nebuchadnezzar and all his army came against Jerusalem again and besieged it.

2.verse: Two years later, in the month of July, they breached the wall, and the city fell,

3.verse: and all the officers of the Babylonian army came in and sat in triumph at the middle gate. Nergal-sharezer was there, Samgar-nebo, Sarsechim, Nergal-sharezer the king’s chief assistant, and many others.

4.verse: When King Zedekiah and his soldiers realized that the city was lost, they fled during the night, going out through the gate between the two walls back of the palace garden and across the fields toward the Jordan Valley.

5.verse: But the Babylonians chased the king and caught him on the plains of Jericho and brought him to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, who was at Riblah in the land of Hamath, where he pronounced judgment upon him.

6.verse: The king of Babylon made Zedekiah watch as they killed his children and all the nobles of Judah.

7.verse: Then he gouged out Zedekiah’s eyes and bound him in chains to send him away to Babylon as a slave.

8.verse: Meanwhile the army burned Jerusalem, including the palace, and tore down the walls of the city.

9.verse: Then Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, and his men sent the remnant of the population and all those who had defected to him to Babylon.

10.verse: But throughout the land of Judah he left a few people, the very poor, and gave them fields and vineyards.

11.verse: Meanwhile King Nebuchadnezzar had told Nebuzaradan to find Jeremiah. “See that he isn’t hurt,” he said. “Look after him well and give him anything he wants.”

12.verse: Meanwhile King Nebuchadnezzar had told Nebuzaradan to find Jeremiah. “See that he isn’t hurt,” he said. “Look after him well and give him anything he wants.”

13.verse: So Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, and Nebushazban, the chief of the eunuchs, and Nergal-sharezer, the king’s advisor, and all the officials took steps to do as the king had commanded.

14.verse: They sent soldiers to bring Jeremiah out of the prison, and put him into the care of Gedaliah (son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan), to take him back to his home. And Jeremiah lived there among his people who were left in the land.

15.verse: The Lord gave the following message to Jeremiah before the Babylonians arrived, while he was still in prison:

16.verse: “Send this word to Ebed-melech the Ethiopian: The Lord, the God of Israel, says: I will do to this city everything I threatened; I will destroy it before your eyes,

17.verse: but I will deliver you. You shall not be killed by those you fear so much.

18.verse: As a reward for trusting me, I will preserve your life and keep you safe.”

1.verse: Nebuzaradan, captain of the guard, took Jeremiah to Ramah along with all the exiled people of Jerusalem and Judah who were being sent to Babylon, but then released him.

2.verse: The captain called for Jeremiah and said, “The Lord your God has brought this disaster on this land, just as he said he would. For these people have sinned against the Lord. That is why it happened.

3.verse: The captain called for Jeremiah and said, “The Lord your God has brought this disaster on this land, just as he said he would. For these people have sinned against the Lord. That is why it happened.

4.verse: Now I am going to take off your chains and let you go. If you want to come with me to Babylon, fine; I will see that you are well cared for. But if you don’t want to come, don’t. The world is before you—go where you like.

5.verse: If you decide to stay, then return to Gedaliah, who has been appointed as governor of Judah by the king of Babylon, and stay with the remnant he rules. But it’s up to you; go where you like.” Then Nebuzaradan gave Jeremiah some food and money and let him go.

6.verse: So Jeremiah returned to Gedaliah and lived in Judah with the people left in the land.

7.verse: Now when the leaders of the Jewish guerrilla bands in the countryside heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah as governor over the poor of the land who were left behind, and had not exiled everyone to Babylon,

8.verse: they came to see Gedaliah at Mizpah, where his headquarters were. These are the names of the leaders who came: Ishmael (son of Nethaniah), Johanan and Jonathan (sons of Kareah), Seraiah (son of Tanhumeth), the sons of Ephai (the Netophathite), Jezaniah (son of a Maacathite), and their men.

9.verse: And Gedaliah assured them that it would be safe to surrender to the Babylonians. “Stay here and serve the king of Babylon,” he said, “and all will go well for you.

10.verse: As for me, I will stay at Mizpah and intercede for you with the Babylonians who will come here to oversee my administration. Settle in any city you wish and live off the land. Harvest the grapes and summer fruits and olives and store them away.”

11.verse: When the Jews in Moab and among the Ammonites and in Edom and the other nearby countries heard that a few people were still left in Judah, and that the king of Babylon had not taken them all away, and that Gedaliah was the governor,

12.verse: they all began to return to Judah from the many places to which they had fled. They stopped at Mizpah to discuss their plans with Gedaliah and then went out to the deserted farms and gathered a great harvest of wine grapes and other crops.

13.verse: But soon afterwards Johanan (son of Kareah) and the other guerrilla leaders came to Mizpah to warn Gedaliah that Baalis, king of the Ammonites, had sent Ishmael (son of Nethaniah) to assassinate him. But Gedaliah wouldn’t believe them.

14.verse: But soon afterwards Johanan (son of Kareah) and the other guerrilla leaders came to Mizpah to warn Gedaliah that Baalis, king of the Ammonites, had sent Ishmael (son of Nethaniah) to assassinate him. But Gedaliah wouldn’t believe them.

15.verse: Then Johanan had a private conference with Gedaliah. Johanan volunteered to kill Ishmael secretly. “Why should we let him come and murder you?” Johanan asked. “What will happen then to the Jews who have returned? Why should this remnant be scattered and lost?”

16.verse: But Gedaliah said, “I forbid you to do any such thing, for you are lying about Ishmael.”

1.verse: But in October, Ishmael (son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama), who was a member of the royal family and one of the king’s top officials, arrived in Mizpah, accompanied by ten men. Gedaliah invited them to dinner.

2.verse: While they were eating, Ishmael and the ten men in league with him suddenly jumped up, pulled out their swords, and killed Gedaliah.

3.verse: Then they went out and slaughtered all the Jewish officials and Babylonian soldiers who were in Mizpah with Gedaliah.

4.verse: The next day, before the outside world knew what had happened,

5.verse: eighty men approached Mizpah from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria, to worship at the Temple of the Lord. They had shaved off their beards, torn their clothes, and cut themselves, and were bringing offerings and incense.

6.verse: Ishmael went out from the city to meet them, crying as he went. When he faced them he said, “Oh, come and see what has happened to Gedaliah!”

7.verse: Then, when they were all inside the city, Ishmael and his men killed all but ten of them and threw their bodies into a cistern.

8.verse: The ten had talked Ishmael into letting them go by promising to bring him their treasures of wheat, barley, oil, and honey they had hidden away.

9.verse: The cistern where Ishmael dumped the bodies of the men he murdered was the large one constructed by King Asa when he fortified Mizpah to protect himself against Baasha, king of Israel.

10.verse: Ishmael made captives of the king’s daughters and of the people who had been left under Gedaliah’s care in Mizpah by Nebuzaradan, captain of the guard. Soon after, he took them with him when he headed toward the country of the Ammonites.

11.verse: But when Johanan (son of Kareah) and the rest of the guerrilla leaders heard what Ishmael had done,

12.verse: they took all their men and set out to stop him. They caught up with him at the pool near Gibeon.

13.verse: The people with Ishmael shouted for joy when they saw Johanan and his men and ran to meet them.

14.verse: The people with Ishmael shouted for joy when they saw Johanan and his men and ran to meet them.

15.verse: Meanwhile Ishmael escaped with eight of his men into the land of the Ammonites.

16.verse: Then Johanan and his men went to the village of Geruth Chimham, near Bethlehem, taking with them all those they had rescued—soldiers, women, children, and eunuchs, to prepare to leave for Egypt.

17.verse: Then Johanan and his men went to the village of Geruth Chimham, near Bethlehem, taking with them all those they had rescued—soldiers, women, children, and eunuchs, to prepare to leave for Egypt.

18.verse: For they were afraid of what the Babylonians would do when the news reached them that Ishmael had killed Gedaliah the governor, for he had been chosen and appointed by the Babylonian emperor.

1.verse: Then Johanan and the army captains and all the people, great and small, came to Jeremiah

2.verse: and said, “Please pray for us to the Lord your God, for as you know so well, we are only a tiny remnant of what we were before.

3.verse: Beg the Lord your God to show us what to do and where to go.”

4.verse: “All right,” Jeremiah replied. “I will ask him and I will tell you what he says. I will hide nothing from you.”

5.verse: Then they said to Jeremiah, “May the curse of God be on us if we refuse to obey whatever he says we should do!

6.verse: Whether we like it or not, we will obey the Lord our God, to whom we send you with our plea. For if we obey him, everything will turn out well for us.”

7.verse: Ten days later the Lord gave his reply to Jeremiah.

8.verse: So he called for Johanan and the captains of his forces, and for all the people, great and small,

9.verse: and said to them: “You sent me to the Lord, the God of Israel, with your request, and this is his reply:

10.verse: “Stay here in this land. If you do, I will bless you, and no one will harm you. For I am sorry for all the punishment I have had to give to you.

11.verse: Don’t fear the king of Babylon anymore, for I am with you to save you and to deliver you from his hand.

12.verse: And I will be merciful to you by making him kind so that he will not kill you or make slaves of you but will let you stay here in your land.

13.verse: “But if you refuse to obey the Lord and say, ‘We will not stay here,’—and insist on going to Egypt where you think you will be free from war and hunger and alarms,

14.verse: “But if you refuse to obey the Lord and say, ‘We will not stay here,’—and insist on going to Egypt where you think you will be free from war and hunger and alarms,

15.verse: then this is what the Lord replies, O remnant of Judah: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: If you insist on going to Egypt,

16.verse: the war and famine you fear will follow close behind you, and you will perish there.

17.verse: That is the fate awaiting every one of you who insists on going to live in Egypt. Yes, you will die from sword, famine, and disease. None of you will escape from the evil I will bring upon you there.

18.verse: “For the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Just as my anger and fury were poured out upon the people of Jerusalem, so it will be poured out on you when you enter Egypt. You will be received with disgust and with hatred—you will be cursed and reviled. And you will never again see your own land.

19.verse: For the Lord has said: O remnant of Judah, do not go to Egypt!” Jeremiah concluded: “Never forget the warning I have given you today.

20.verse: If you go, it will be at the cost of your lives. For you were deceitful when you sent me to pray for you and said, ‘Just tell us what God says and we will do it!’

21.verse: And today I have told you exactly what he said, but you will not obey any more now than you did the other times.

22.verse: Therefore know for a certainty that you will die by sword, famine, and disease in Egypt, where you insist on going.”

1.verse: When Jeremiah had finished giving this message from God to all the people,

2.verse: Azariah (son of Hoshaiah) and Johanan (son of Kareah) and all the other proud men said to Jeremiah, “You lie! The Lord our God hasn’t told you to tell us not to go to Egypt! Baruch (son of Neriah) has plotted against us and told you to say this so that we will stay here and be killed by the Babylonians or carried off to Babylon as slaves.”

3.verse: Azariah (son of Hoshaiah) and Johanan (son of Kareah) and all the other proud men said to Jeremiah, “You lie! The Lord our God hasn’t told you to tell us not to go to Egypt! Baruch (son of Neriah) has plotted against us and told you to say this so that we will stay here and be killed by the Babylonians or carried off to Babylon as slaves.”

4.verse: So Johanan and all the guerrilla leaders and all the people refused to obey the Lord and stay in Judah.

5.verse: All of them, including all those who had returned from the nearby countries where they had fled, now started off for Egypt with Johanan and the other captains in command.

6.verse: In the crowd were men, women, and children, the king’s daughters, and all those whom Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had left with Gedaliah. They even forced Jeremiah and Baruch to go with them too.

7.verse: And so they arrived in Egypt at the city of Tahpanhes, for they would not obey the Lord.

8.verse: Then at Tahpanhes, the Lord spoke to Jeremiah again and said:

9.verse: “Call together the men of Judah and, as they watch you, bury large rocks between the pavement stones at the entrance of Pharaoh’s palace here in Tahpanhes,

10.verse: and tell the men of Judah this: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: I will surely bring Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, here to Egypt, for he is my servant. I will set his throne upon these stones that I have hidden. He shall spread his royal canopy over them.

11.verse: And when he comes, he shall destroy the land of Egypt, killing all those I want killed and capturing those I want captured, and many shall die of plague.

12.verse: He will set fire to the temples of the gods of Egypt and burn the idols and carry off the people as his captives. And he shall plunder the land of Egypt as a shepherd picks fleas from his cloak! And he himself shall leave unharmed.

13.verse: And he shall break down the obelisks standing in the city of Heliopolis and burn down the temples of the gods of Egypt.”

1.verse: This is the message God gave to Jeremiah concerning all the Jews who were living in the north of Egypt in the cities of Migdol, Tahpanhes, and Memphis, and throughout southern Egypt as well:

2.verse: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: You saw what I did to Jerusalem and to all the cities of Judah. Because of all their wickedness they lie in heaps and ashes, without a living soul. For my anger rose high against them for worshiping other gods—“gods” that neither they nor you nor any of your fathers have ever known.

3.verse: The Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, says: You saw what I did to Jerusalem and to all the cities of Judah. Because of all their wickedness they lie in heaps and ashes, without a living soul. For my anger rose high against them for worshiping other gods—“gods” that neither they nor you nor any of your fathers have ever known.

4.verse: I sent my servants, the prophets, to protest over and over again and to plead with them not to do this horrible thing I hate,

5.verse: but they wouldn’t listen and wouldn’t turn back from their wicked ways; they have kept right on with their sacrifices to these “gods.”

6.verse: And so my fury and anger boiled over and fell as fire upon the cities of Judah and into the streets of Jerusalem, and there is desolation until this day.

7.verse: And now the Lord, the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, asks you: Why are you destroying yourselves? For not one of you shall live—not a man, woman, or child among you who has come here from Judah, not even the babies in arms.

8.verse: For you are rousing my anger with the idols you have made and worshiped here in Egypt, burning incense to them, and causing me to destroy you completely and to make you a curse and a stench in the nostrils of all the nations of the earth.

9.verse: Have you forgotten the sins of your fathers, the sins of the kings and queens of Judah, your own sins, and the sins of your wives in Judah and Jerusalem?

10.verse: And even until this very hour there has been no apology; no one has wanted to return to me or follow the laws I gave you and your fathers before you.

11.verse: Therefore the Lord, the God of Israel, says: There is fury in my face and I will destroy every one of you!

12.verse: I will take this remnant of Judah that insisted on coming here to Egypt, and I will consume them. They shall fall here in Egypt, killed by famine and sword; all shall die, from the least important to the greatest. They shall be despised and loathed, cursed and hated.

13.verse: I will punish them in Egypt just as I punished them in Jerusalem, by sword, famine, and disease.

14.verse: Not one of them shall escape from my wrath except those who repent of their coming and escape from the others by returning again to their own land.

15.verse: Then all the women present and all the men who knew that their wives had burned incense to idols (it was a great crowd of all the Jews in southern Egypt) answered Jeremiah:

16.verse: “We will not listen to your false ‘Messages from God’!

17.verse: We will do whatever we want to. We will burn incense to the Queen of Heaven and sacrifice to her just as much as we like—just as we and our fathers before us, and our kings and princes have always done in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem; for in those days we had plenty to eat, and we were well off and happy!

18.verse: But ever since we quit burning incense to the Queen of Heaven and stopped worshiping her, we have been in great trouble and have been destroyed by sword and famine.”

19.verse: “And,” the women added, “do you suppose that we were worshiping the Queen of Heaven and pouring out our libations to her and making cakes for her with her image on them, without our husbands knowing it and helping us? Of course not!”

20.verse: Then Jeremiah said to all of them, men and women alike, who had given him that answer:

21.verse: “Do you think the Lord didn’t know that you and your fathers, your kings and princes, and all the people were burning incense to idols in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?

22.verse: It was because he could no longer bear all the evil things you were doing that he made your land desolate, an incredible ruin, cursed, without an inhabitant, as it is today.

23.verse: The very reason all these terrible things have befallen you is because you have burned incense and sinned against the Lord and refused to obey him.”

24.verse: Then Jeremiah said to them all, including the women: “Listen to the word of the Lord, all you citizens of Judah who are here in Egypt!

25.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel, says: Both you and your wives have said that you will never give up your devotion and sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven, and you have proved it by your actions. Then go ahead and carry out your promises and vows to her!

26.verse: But listen to the word of the Lord, all you Jews who are living in the land of Egypt: I have sworn by my great name, says the Lord, that it will do you no good to seek my help and blessing anymore, saying, ‘O Lord our God, help us!’

27.verse: For I will watch over you, but not for good! I will see to it that evil befalls you, and you shall be destroyed by war and famine until all of you are dead.

28.verse: “Only those who return to Judah (it will be but a tiny remnant) shall escape my wrath, but all who refuse to go back—who insist on living in Egypt—shall find out who tells the truth, I or they!

29.verse: And this is the proof I give you that all I have threatened will happen to you and that I will punish you here:

30.verse: I will turn Pharaoh Hophra, king of Egypt, over to those* who seek his life, just as I turned Zedekiah, king of Judah, over to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon.”

1.verse: This is the message Jeremiah gave to Baruch in the fourth year of the reign of King Jehoiakim (son of Josiah), after Baruch had written down all God’s messages as Jeremiah was dictating them to him:

2.verse: O Baruch, the Lord God of Israel says this to you:

3.verse: You have said, Woe is me! Don’t I have troubles enough already? And now the Lord has added more! I am weary of my own sighing and I find no rest.

4.verse: But tell Baruch this, The Lord says: I will destroy this nation that I built; I will wipe out what I established.

5.verse: Are you seeking great things for yourself? Don’t do it! For though I will bring great evil upon all these people, I will protect you wherever you go, as your reward.

1.verse: Here are the messages given to Jeremiah concerning foreign nations: The Egyptians

2.verse: This message was given against Egypt at the occasion of the battle of Carchemish when Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt, and his army were defeated beside the Euphrates River by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, in the fourth year of the reign of Jehoiakim (son of Josiah), king of Judah:

3.verse: Buckle on your armor, you Egyptians, and advance to battle!

4.verse: Harness the horses and prepare to mount them—don your helmets, sharpen your spears, put on your armor.

5.verse: But look! The Egyptian army flees in terror; the mightiest of its soldiers run without a backward glance. Yes, terror shall surround them on every side, says the Lord.

6.verse: The swift will not escape, nor the mightiest of warriors. In the north, by the river Euphrates, they have stumbled and fallen.

7.verse: What is this mighty army, rising like the Nile at flood time, overflowing all the land?

8.verse: It is the Egyptian army, boasting that it will cover the earth like a flood, destroying every foe.

9.verse: Then come, O horses and chariots and mighty soldiers of Egypt! Come, all of you from Cush and Put and Lud who handle the shield and bend the bow!

10.verse: For this is the day of the Lord, the Lord Almighty, a day of vengeance upon his enemies. The sword shall devour until it is sated, yes, drunk with your blood, for the Lord, the Lord Almighty will receive a sacrifice today in the north country beside the river Euphrates!

11.verse: Go up to Gilead for medicine, O virgin daughter of Egypt! Yet there is no cure for your wounds. Though you have used many medicines, there is no healing for you.

12.verse: The nations have heard of your shame. The earth is filled with your cry of despair and defeat; your mightiest soldiers will stumble across each other and fall together.

13.verse: Then God gave Jeremiah this message concerning the coming of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, to attack Egypt:

14.verse: Shout it out in Egypt; publish it in the cities of Migdol, Memphis, and Tahpanhes! Mobilize for battle, for the sword of destruction shall devour all around you.

15.verse: Why has Apis, your bull god, fled in terror? Because the Lord knocked him down before your enemies.

16.verse: Vast multitudes fall in heaps. (Then the remnant of the Jews will say, “Come, let us return again to Judah where we were born and get away from all this slaughter here!”)

17.verse: Rename Pharaoh Hophra and call him “The Man with No Power but with Plenty of Noise!”

18.verse: As I live, says the King, the Lord of Hosts, one is coming against Egypt who is as tall as Mount Tabor or Mount Carmel by the sea!

19.verse: Pack up; get ready to leave for exile, you citizens of Egypt, for the city of Memphis shall be utterly destroyed and left without a soul alive.

20.verse: Egypt is sleek as a heifer, but a gadfly sends her running—a gadfly from the north! Even her famed mercenaries have become like frightened calves. They turn and run, for it is the day of great calamity for Egypt, a time of great punishment.

21.verse: Egypt is sleek as a heifer, but a gadfly sends her running—a gadfly from the north! Even her famed mercenaries have become like frightened calves. They turn and run, for it is the day of great calamity for Egypt, a time of great punishment.

22.verse: Silent as a serpent gliding away, Egypt flees; the invading army marches in. The numberless soldiers cut down your people like woodsmen who clear a forest of its trees.

23.verse: Silent as a serpent gliding away, Egypt flees; the invading army marches in. The numberless soldiers cut down your people like woodsmen who clear a forest of its trees.

24.verse: Egypt is as helpless as a girl before these men from the north.

25.verse: The Lord, the God of Israel, says: I will punish Amon, god of Thebes, and all the other gods of Egypt. I will punish Pharaoh too, and all who trust in him.

26.verse: I will deliver them into the hands of those who want them killed—into the hands of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and his army. But afterwards the land shall recover from the ravages of war.

27.verse: But don’t you be afraid, O my people who return to your own land, don’t be dismayed; for I will save you from far away and bring your children from a distant land. Yes, Israel shall return and be at rest, and nothing shall make her afraid.

28.verse: Fear not, O Jacob, my servant, says the Lord, for I am with you. I will destroy all the nations to which I have exiled you, but I will not destroy you. I will punish you, but only enough to correct you.

1.verse: The Philistines This is God’s message to Jeremiah concerning the Philistines of Gaza, before the city was captured by the Egyptian army:

2.verse: The Lord says: A flood is coming from the north to overflow the land of the Philistines; it will destroy their cities and everything in them. Strong men will scream in terror, and all the land will weep.

3.verse: Hear the clattering hoofs and rumbling wheels as the chariots go rushing by; fathers flee without a backward glance at their helpless children,

4.verse: for the time has come when all the Philistines and their allies from Tyre and Sidon will be destroyed. For the Lord is destroying the Philistines, those colonists from Caphtor.

5.verse: The cities of Gaza and Ashkelon will be razed to the ground and lie in ruins. O descendants of the Anakim, how you will lament and mourn!

6.verse: O sword of the Lord, when will you be at rest again? Go back into your scabbard; rest and be still!

7.verse: But how can it be still when the Lord has sent it on an errand? For the city of Ashkelon and those living along the sea must be destroyed.

1.verse: The Moabites This is the message of the Lord of Hosts, the God of Israel, against Moab: Woe to the city of Nebo, for it shall lie in ruins. The city of Kiriathaim and its forts are overwhelmed and captured.

2.verse: No one will ever brag about Moab anymore, for there is a plot against her life. In Heshbon plans have been completed to destroy her. “Come,” they say, “we will cut her off from being a nation.” In Madmen all is silent. And then the roar of battle will surge against Horonaim, for all Moab is being destroyed. Her crying will be heard as far away as Zoar.

3.verse: No one will ever brag about Moab anymore, for there is a plot against her life. In Heshbon plans have been completed to destroy her. “Come,” they say, “we will cut her off from being a nation.” In Madmen all is silent. And then the roar of battle will surge against Horonaim, for all Moab is being destroyed. Her crying will be heard as far away as Zoar.

4.verse: No one will ever brag about Moab anymore, for there is a plot against her life. In Heshbon plans have been completed to destroy her. “Come,” they say, “we will cut her off from being a nation.” In Madmen all is silent. And then the roar of battle will surge against Horonaim, for all Moab is being destroyed. Her crying will be heard as far away as Zoar.

5.verse: Her refugees will climb the hills of Luhith, weeping bitterly, while cries of terror rise from the city below.

6.verse: Flee for your lives; hide in the wilderness!

7.verse: For you trusted in your wealth and skill; therefore, you shall perish. Your god Chemosh, with his priests and princes, shall be taken away to distant lands!

8.verse: All the villages and cities, whether they be on the plateaus or in the valleys, shall be destroyed, for the Lord has said it.

9.verse: Oh, for wings for Moab that she could fly away, for her cities shall be left without a living soul.

10.verse: Cursed be those withholding their swords from your blood, refusing to do the work that God has given them!

11.verse: From her earliest history Moab has lived there undisturbed from all invasions. She is like wine that has not been poured from flask to flask and is fragrant and smooth. But now she shall have the pouring out of exile!

12.verse: The time is coming soon, the Lord has said, when he will send troublemakers to spill her out from jar to jar and then shatter the jars!

13.verse: Then at last Moab shall be ashamed of her idol Chemosh, as Israel was of her calf idol at Bethel.

14.verse: Do you remember that boast of yours: “We are heroes, mighty men of war”?

15.verse: But now Moab is to be destroyed; her destroyer is on the way; her choicest youth are doomed to slaughter, says the King, the Lord Almighty.

16.verse: Calamity is coming fast to Moab.

17.verse: O friends of Moab, weep for her and cry! See how the strong, the beautiful is shattered!

18.verse: Come down from your glory and sit in the dust, O people of Dibon, for those destroying Moab shall shatter Dibon too, and tear down all her towers.

19.verse: Those in Aroer stand anxiously beside the road to watch, and shout to those who flee from Moab, “What has happened there?”

20.verse: And they reply, “Moab lies in ruins; weep and wail. Tell it by the banks of the Arnon, that Moab is destroyed.”

21.verse: All the cities of the tableland lie in ruins too, for God’s judgment has been poured out upon them all—on Holon and Jahzah and Mephaath,

22.verse: and Dibon and Nebo and Beth-diblathaim,

23.verse: and Kiriathaim and Beth-gamul and Beth-meon,

24.verse: and Kerioth and Bozrah—and all the cities of the land of Moab, far and near.

25.verse: The strength of Moab is ended—her horns are cut off; her arms are broken.

26.verse: Let her stagger and fall like a drunkard, for she has rebelled against the Lord. Moab shall wallow in her vomit, scorned by all.

27.verse: For you scorned Israel and robbed her and were happy at her fall.

28.verse: O people of Moab, flee from your cities and live in the caves like doves that nest in the clefts of the rocks.

29.verse: We have all heard of the pride of Moab, for it is very great. We know your loftiness, your arrogance, and your haughty heart.

30.verse: I know her insolence, the Lord has said, but her boasts are false—her helplessness is great.

31.verse: Yes, I wail for Moab, my heart is broken for the men of Kir-heres.

32.verse: O men of Sibmah, rich in vineyards, I weep for you even more than for Jazer. For the destroyer has cut off your spreading tendrils and harvested your grapes and summer fruits. He has plucked you bare!

33.verse: Joy and gladness are gone from fruitful Moab. The presses yield no wine; no one treads the grapes with shouts of joy. There is shouting, yes, but not the shouting of joy.

34.verse: Instead the awful cries of terror and pain rise from all over the land—from Heshbon clear across to Elealeh and to Jahaz; from Zoar to Horonaim and to Eglath-shelishiyah. The pastures of Nimrim are deserted now.

35.verse: For the Lord says: I have put a stop to Moab’s worshiping false gods and burning incense to idols.

36.verse: Sadly sings my heart for Moab and Kir-heres, for all their wealth has disappeared.

37.verse: They shave their heads and beards in anguish; they slash their hands and put on clothes of sackcloth.

38.verse: Crying and sorrow will be in every Moabite home and on the streets; for I have smashed and shattered Moab like an old, unwanted bottle.

39.verse: How it is broken! Hear the wails! See the shame of Moab! For she is a sign of horror and of scoffing to her neighbors now.

40.verse: A vulture circles ominously above the land of Moab, says the Lord.

41.verse: Her cities are fallen; her strongholds are seized. The hearts of her mightiest warriors fail with fear like women in the pains of giving birth.

42.verse: Moab shall no longer be a nation, for she has boasted against the Lord.

43.verse: Fear and traps and treachery shall be your lot, O Moab, says the Lord.

44.verse: He who flees shall fall in a trap, and he who escapes from the trap shall run into a snare. I will see to it that you do not get away, for the time of your judgment has come.

45.verse: They flee to Heshbon, unable to go farther. But a fire comes from Heshbon—Sihon’s ancestral home—and devours the land from end to end with all its rebellious people.

46.verse: Woe to you, O Moab; the people of the god Chemosh are destroyed, and your sons and daughters are taken away as slaves.

47.verse: But in the latter days, says the Lord, I will reestablish Moab. (Here the prophecy concerning Moab ends.)

1.verse: The Ammonites What is this you are doing? Why are you living in the cities of the Jews? Aren’t there Jews enough to fill them up? Didn’t they inherit them from me? Why then have you, who worship Milcom, taken over Gad and all its cities?

2.verse: I will punish you for this, the Lord declares, by destroying your city of Rabbah. It shall become a desolate heap, and the neighboring towns shall be burned. Then Israel shall come and take back her land from you again. She shall dispossess those who dispossessed her, says the Lord.

3.verse: Cry out, O Heshbon, for Ai is destroyed! Weep, daughter of Rabbah! Put on garments of mourning; weep and wail, hiding in the hedges, for your god Milcom shall be exiled along with his princes and priests.

4.verse: You are proud of your fertile valleys, but they will soon be ruined. O wicked daughter, you trusted in your wealth and thought no one could ever harm you.

5.verse: But see, I will bring terror upon you, says the Lord, the Lord Almighty. For all your neighbors shall drive you from your land and none shall help your exiles as they flee.

6.verse: But afterward I will restore the fortunes of the Ammonites, says the Lord. The Edomites

7.verse: The Lord says: Where are all your wise men of days gone by? Is there not one left in all of Teman?

8.verse: Flee to the remotest parts of the desert, O people of Dedan; for when I punish Edom, I will punish you!

9.verse: Those who gather grapes leave a few for the poor, and even thieves don’t take everything, but I will strip bare the land of Esau, and there will be no place to hide. Her children, her brothers, her neighbors—all will be destroyed—and she herself will perish too.

10.verse: Those who gather grapes leave a few for the poor, and even thieves don’t take everything, but I will strip bare the land of Esau, and there will be no place to hide. Her children, her brothers, her neighbors—all will be destroyed—and she herself will perish too.

11.verse: (But I will preserve your fatherless children who remain, and let your widows depend upon me.)

12.verse: The Lord says to Edom: If the innocent must suffer, how much more must you! You shall not go unpunished! You must drink this cup of judgment!

13.verse: For I have sworn by my own name, says the Lord, that Bozrah shall become heaps of ruins, cursed and mocked; and her cities shall be eternal wastes.

14.verse: I have heard this message from the Lord: I have sent a messenger to call the nations to form a coalition against Edom and destroy her.

15.verse: I will make her weak among the nations and despised by all, says the Lord.

16.verse: You have been fooled by your fame and your pride, living there in the mountains of Petra, in the clefts of the rocks. But though you live among the peaks with the eagles, I will bring you down, says the Lord.

17.verse: The fate of Edom will be horrible; all who go by will be appalled and gasp at the sight.

18.verse: Your cities will become as silent as Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighboring towns, says the Lord. No one will live there anymore.

19.verse: I will send against them one who will come like a lion from the wilds of Jordan stalking the sheep in the fold. Suddenly Edom shall be destroyed, and I will appoint over the Edomites the person of my choice. For who is like me, and who can call me to account? What shepherd can defy me?

20.verse: Take note: The Lord will certainly do this to Edom and also the people of Teman—even little children will be dragged away as slaves! It will be a shocking thing to see.

21.verse: The earth shakes with the noise of Edom’s fall; the cry of the people is heard as far away as the Red Sea.

22.verse: The one who will come will fly as swift as a vulture and will spread his wings against Bozrah. Then the courage of the mightiest warriors will disappear like that of women in labor. Damascus

23.verse: The cities of Hamath and Arpad are stricken with fear, for they have heard the news of their doom. Their hearts are troubled like a wild sea in a raging storm.

24.verse: Damascus has become feeble, and all her people turn to flee. Fear, anguish, and sorrow have gripped her as they do women in labor.

25.verse: O famous city, city of joy, how you are forsaken now!

26.verse: Your young men lie dead in the streets; your entire army shall be destroyed in one day, says the Lord Almighty.

27.verse: And I will start a fire at the edge of Damascus that shall burn up the palaces of Ben-hadad. Kedar and Hazor

28.verse: This prophecy is about Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor* that are going to be destroyed by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, for the Lord will send him to destroy them:

29.verse: Their flocks and their tents will be captured, says the Lord, with all their household goods. Their camels will be taken away, and all around will be the shouts of panic, “We are surrounded and doomed!”

30.verse: Flee for your lives, says the Lord. Go deep into the deserts, O people of Hazor, for Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, has plotted against you and is preparing to destroy you.

31.verse: “Go,” said the Lord to King Nebuchadnezzar. “Attack those wealthy Bedouin tribes living alone in the desert without a care in the world, boasting that they are self-sufficient—that they need neither walls nor gates.

32.verse: Their camels and cattle shall all be yours, and I will scatter these heathen to the winds. From all directions I will bring calamity upon them.

33.verse: “Hazor shall be a home for wild animals of the desert. No one shall ever live there again. It shall be desolate forever.” Elam

34.verse: God’s message against Elam came to Jeremiah in the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah:

35.verse: The Lord says: I will destroy the army of Elam,

36.verse: and I will scatter the people of Elam to the four winds; they shall be exiled to countries throughout the world.

37.verse: My fierce anger will bring great evil upon Elam, says the Lord, and I will cause her enemies to wipe her out.

38.verse: And I will set my throne in Elam, says the Lord. I will destroy her king and princes.

39.verse: But in the latter days I will bring the people back, says the Lord.

1.verse: Babylon This is the message from the Lord against Babylon and the Chaldeans, spoken by Jeremiah the prophet:

2.verse: Tell all the world that Babylon will be destroyed; her god Marduk will be utterly disgraced!

3.verse: For a nation shall come down upon her from the north with such destruction that no one shall live in her again; all shall be gone—both men and animals shall flee.

4.verse: Then the people of Israel and Judah shall join together, weeping and seeking the Lord their God.

5.verse: They shall ask the way to Zion and start back home again. “Come,” they will say, “let us be united to the Lord with an eternal pledge that will never be broken again.”

6.verse: My people have been lost sheep. Their shepherds led them astray and then turned them loose in the mountains. They lost their way and didn’t remember how to get back to the fold.

7.verse: All who found them devoured them and said, “We are permitted to attack them freely, for they have sinned against the Lord, the God of justice, the hope of their fathers.”

8.verse: But now, flee from Babylon, the land of the Chaldeans; lead my people home again.

9.verse: For see, I am raising up an army of great nations from the north, and I will bring them against Babylon to attack her, and she shall be destroyed. The enemies’ arrows go straight to the mark; they do not miss!

10.verse: And Babylon shall be sacked until everyone is sated with loot,” says the Lord.

11.verse: Though you were glad, O Chaldeans, plunderers of my people, and are fat as cows that feed in lush pastures, and neigh like stallions,

12.verse: yet your mother shall be overwhelmed with shame, for you shall become the least of the nations—a wilderness, a dry and desert land.

13.verse: Because of the anger of the Lord, Babylon shall become deserted wasteland, and all who pass by shall be appalled and shall mock at her for all her wounds.

14.verse: Yes, prepare to fight with Babylon, all you nations round about; let the archers shoot at her; spare no arrows, for she has sinned against the Lord.

15.verse: Shout against her from every side. Look! She surrenders! Her walls have fallen. The Lord has taken vengeance. Do to her as she has done!

16.verse: Let the farmhands all depart. Let them rush back to their own lands as the enemies advance.

17.verse: The Israelites are like sheep the lions chase. First the king of Assyria ate them up; then Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, crunched their bones.

18.verse: Therefore the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Now I will punish the king of Babylon and his land as I punished the king of Assyria.

19.verse: And I will bring Israel home again to her own land, to feed in the fields of Carmel and Bashan and to be happy once more on Mount Ephraim and Mount Gilead.

20.verse: In those days, says the Lord, no sin shall be found in Israel or in Judah, for I will pardon the remnant I preserve.

21.verse: Go up, O my warriors, against the land of Merathaim and against the people of Pekod.* Yes, march against Babylon, the land of rebels, a land that I will judge! Annihilate them, as I have commanded you.

22.verse: Let there be the shout of battle in the land, a shout of great destruction.

23.verse: Babylon, the mightiest hammer in all the earth, lies broken and shattered. Babylon is desolate among the nations!

24.verse: O Babylon, I have set a trap for you and you are caught, for you have fought against the Lord.

25.verse: The Lord has opened his armory and brought out weapons to explode his wrath upon his enemies. The terror that befalls Babylon will be the work of the Lord God.

26.verse: Yes, come against her from distant lands; break open her granaries; knock down her walls and houses into heaps of ruins and utterly destroy her; let nothing be left.

27.verse: Not even her cattle—woe to them too! Kill them all! For the time has come for Babylon to be devastated.

28.verse: But my people will flee; they will escape back to their own country to tell how the Lord their God has broken forth in fury upon those who destroyed his Temple.

29.verse: Send out a call for archers to come to Babylon; surround the city so that none can escape. Do to her as she has done to others, for she has haughtily defied the Lord, the Holy One of Israel.

30.verse: Her young men will fall in the streets and die; her warriors will all be killed.

31.verse: For see, I am against you, O people so proud; and now your day of reckoning has come.

32.verse: Land of pride, you will stumble and fall, and no one will raise you up; for the Lord will light a fire in the cities of Babylon that will burn everything around them.

33.verse: The Lord says: The people of Israel and Judah have been wronged. Their captors hold them and refuse to let them go.

34.verse: But their Redeemer is strong. His name is the Lord Almighty. He will plead for them and see that they are freed to live again in quietness in Israel. As for the people of Babylon—there is no rest for them!

35.verse: The sword of destruction shall smite the Chaldeans, says the Lord. It shall smite the people of Babylon—her princes and wise men too.

36.verse: All her wise counselors shall become fools! Panic shall seize her mightiest warriors!

37.verse: War shall devour her horses and chariots, and her allies from other lands shall become as weak as women. Her treasures shall all be robbed;

38.verse: even her water supply will fail. And why? Because the whole land is full of images, and the people are madly in love with their idols.

39.verse: Therefore this city of Babylon shall become inhabited by ostriches and jackals; it shall be a home for the wild animals of the desert. Never again shall it be lived in by human beings; it shall lie desolate forever.

40.verse: The Lord declares that he will destroy Babylon just as he destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighboring towns. No one has lived in them since, and no one will live again in Babylon.

41.verse: See them coming! A great army from the north! It is accompanied by many kings called by God from many lands.

42.verse: They are fully armed for slaughter; they are cruel and show no mercy; their battle cry roars like the surf against the shoreline. O Babylon, they ride against you fully ready for the battle.

43.verse: When the king of Babylon received the dispatch, his hands fell helpless at his sides; pangs of terror gripped him like the pangs of a woman in labor.

44.verse: I will send against them an invader who will come upon them suddenly, like a lion from the jungles of Jordan that leaps upon the grazing sheep. I will put her defenders to flight and appoint over them whomsoever I please. For who is like me? What ruler can oppose my will? Who can call me to account?

45.verse: Listen to the plan of the Lord against Babylon, the land of the Chaldeans. For even little children shall be dragged away as slaves; oh, the horror; oh, the terror.

46.verse: The whole earth shall shake at Babylon’s fall, and her cry of despair shall be heard around the world.

1.verse: The Lord says: I will stir up a destroyer against Babylon, against that whole land of the Chaldeans, and destroy it.

2.verse: Winnowers shall come and winnow her and blow her away; they shall come from every side to rise against her in her day of trouble.

3.verse: The arrows of the enemy shall strike down the bowmen of Babylon and pierce her warriors in their coats of mail. No one shall be spared; both young and old alike shall be destroyed.

4.verse: They shall fall down slain in the land of the Chaldeans, slashed to death in her streets.

5.verse: For the Lord Almighty has not forsaken Israel and Judah. He is still their God, but the land of the Chaldeans is filled with sin against the Holy One of Israel.

6.verse: Flee from Babylon! Save yourselves! Don’t get trapped! If you stay, you will be destroyed when God takes his vengeance on all of Babylon’s sins.

7.verse: Babylon has been as a gold cup in the Lord’s hands, a cup from which he made the whole earth drink and go mad.

8.verse: But now, suddenly Babylon too has fallen. Weep for her; give her medicine; perhaps she can yet be healed.

9.verse: We would help her if we could, but nothing can save her now. Let her go. Abandon her and return to your own land, for God is judging her from heaven.

10.verse: The Lord has vindicated us. Come, let us declare in Jerusalem all the Lord our God has done.

11.verse: Sharpen the arrows! Lift up the shields! For the Lord has stirred up the spirit of the kings of the Medes to march on Babylon and destroy her. This is his vengeance on those who wronged his people and desecrated his Temple.

12.verse: Prepare your defenses, Babylon! Set many watchmen on your walls; send out an ambush, for the Lord will do all he has said he would concerning Babylon.

13.verse: O wealthy port, great center of commerce, your end has come; the thread of your life is cut.

14.verse: The Lord Almighty has taken this vow and sworn to it in his own name: Your cities shall be filled with enemies, like fields filled with locusts in a plague, and they shall lift to the skies their mighty shouts of victory.

15.verse: God made the earth by his power and wisdom. He stretched out the heavens by his understanding.

16.verse: When he speaks, there is thunder in the heavens, and he causes the vapors to rise around the world; he brings the lightning with the rain and the winds from his treasuries.

17.verse: Compared to him, all men are stupid beasts. They have no wisdom—none at all! The silversmith is dulled by the images he makes, for in making them he lies; for he calls them gods when there is not a breath of life in them at all!

18.verse: Idols are nothing! They are lies! And the time is coming when God will come and see, and shall destroy them all.

19.verse: But the God of Israel is no idol! For he made everything there is, and Israel is his nation; the Lord Almighty is his name.

20.verse: Cyrus is God’s battleaxe and sword. I will use you, says the Lord, to break nations in pieces and to destroy many kingdoms.

21.verse: With you I will crush armies, destroying the horse and his rider, the chariot and the charioteer—

22.verse: yes, and the civilians too, both old and young, young men and maidens,

23.verse: shepherds and flocks, farmers and oxen, captains and rulers;

24.verse: before your eyes I will repay Babylon and all the Chaldeans for all the evil they have done to my people, says the Lord.

25.verse: For see, I am against you, O mighty mountain, Babylon, destroyer of the earth! I will lift my hand against you, roll you down from your heights, and leave you, a burnt-out mountain.

26.verse: You shall be desolate forever; even your stones shall never be used for building again. You shall be completely wiped out.

27.verse: Signal many nations to mobilize for war on Babylon. Sound the battle cry; bring out the armies of Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz. Appoint a leader; bring a multitude of horses!

28.verse: Bring against her the armies of the kings of the Medes and their generals, and the armies of all the countries they rule.

29.verse: Babylon trembles and writhes in pain, for all that the Lord has planned against her stands unchanged. Babylon will be left desolate without a living soul.

30.verse: Her mightiest soldiers no longer fight; they stay in their barracks. Their courage is gone; they have become as women. The invaders have burned the houses and broken down the city gates.

31.verse: Messengers from every side come running to the king to tell him all is lost!

32.verse: All the escape routes are blocked; the fortifications are burning, and the army is in panic.

33.verse: For the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Babylon is like the wheat upon a threshing floor; in just a little while the flailing will begin.

34.verse: The Jews in Babylon say, “Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, has eaten and crushed us and emptied out our strength; he has swallowed us like a great monster and filled his belly with our riches; he has cast us out of our own country. May Babylon be repaid for all she did to us! May she be paid in full for all our blood she spilled!”

35.verse: The Jews in Babylon say, “Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, has eaten and crushed us and emptied out our strength; he has swallowed us like a great monster and filled his belly with our riches; he has cast us out of our own country. May Babylon be repaid for all she did to us! May she be paid in full for all our blood she spilled!”

36.verse: And the Lord replies: I will be your lawyer; I will plead your case; I will avenge you. I will dry up her river, her water supply,

37.verse: and Babylon shall become a heap of ruins, haunted by jackals, a land horrible to see, incredible, without a living soul.

38.verse: In their drunken feasts, the men of Babylon roar like lions.

39.verse: And while they lie inflamed with all their wine, I will prepare a different kind of feast for them and make them drink until they fall unconscious to the floor, to sleep forever, never to waken again, says the Lord.

40.verse: I will bring them like lambs to the slaughter, like rams and goats.

41.verse: How Babylon is fallen—great Babylon, lauded by all the earth! The world can scarcely believe its eyes at Babylon’s fall!

42.verse: The sea has risen upon Babylon; she is covered by its waves.

43.verse: Her cities lie in ruins—she is a dry wilderness where no one lives nor even travelers pass by.

44.verse: And I will punish Bel, the god of Babylon, and pull from his mouth what he has taken. The nations shall no longer come and worship him; the wall of Babylon has fallen.

45.verse: O my people, flee from Babylon; save yourselves from the fierce anger of the Lord.

46.verse: But don’t panic when you hear the first rumor of approaching forces. For rumors will keep coming year by year. Then there will be a time of civil war as the governors of Babylon fight against each other.

47.verse: For the time is surely coming when I will punish this great city and all her idols; her dead shall lie in the streets.

48.verse: Heaven and earth shall rejoice, for out of the north shall come destroying armies against Babylon, says the Lord.

49.verse: Just as Babylon killed the people of Israel, so must she be killed.

50.verse: Go, you who escaped the sword! Don’t stand and watch—flee while you can! Remember the Lord and return to Jerusalem far away!

51.verse: “We are ashamed because the Temple of the Lord has been defiled by foreigners from Babylon.”

52.verse: Yes, says the Lord. But the time is coming for the destruction of the idols of Babylon. All through the land will be heard the groans of the wounded.

53.verse: Though Babylon be as powerful as heaven, though she increase her strength immeasurably, she shall die, says the Lord.

54.verse: Listen! Hear the cry of great destruction out of Babylon, the land the Chaldeans rule!

55.verse: For the Lord is destroying Babylon; her mighty voice is stilled as the waves roar in upon her.

56.verse: Destroying armies come and slay her mighty men; all her weapons break in her hands, for the Lord God gives just punishment and is giving Babylon all her due.

57.verse: I will make drunk her princes, wise men, rulers, captains, warriors. They shall sleep and not wake up again! So says the King, the Lord Almighty.

58.verse: For the wide walls of Babylon shall be leveled to the ground, and her high gates shall be burned; the builders from many lands have worked in vain—their work shall be destroyed by fire!

59.verse: During the fourth year of Zedekiah’s reign, this message came to Jeremiah to give to Seraiah (son of Neriah, son of Mahseiah), concerning Seraiah’s capture and exile to Babylon along with Zedekiah, king of Judah. (Seraiah was quartermaster of Zedekiah’s army.)

60.verse: Jeremiah wrote on a scroll all the terrible things God had scheduled against Babylon—all the words written above—

61.verse: and gave the scroll to Seraiah and said to him, “When you get to Babylon, read what I have written and say, ‘Lord, you have said that you will destroy Babylon so that not a living creature will remain, and it will be abandoned forever.’

62.verse: and gave the scroll to Seraiah and said to him, “When you get to Babylon, read what I have written and say, ‘Lord, you have said that you will destroy Babylon so that not a living creature will remain, and it will be abandoned forever.’

63.verse: Then, when you have finished reading the scroll, tie a rock to it, and throw it into the Euphrates River,

64.verse: and say, ‘So shall Babylon sink, never more to rise, because of the evil I am bringing upon her.’” (This ends Jeremiah’s messages.)

1.verse: (Events told about in chapter 39.) Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal (daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah).

2.verse: But he was a wicked king, just as Jehoiakim had been.

3.verse: Things became so bad at last that the Lord, in his anger, saw to it that Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon until he and the people of Israel were ejected from the Lord’s presence in Jerusalem and Judah, and were taken away as captives to Babylon.

4.verse: In the ninth year of Zedekiah’s reign, on the tenth day of the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, came with all his army against Jerusalem and built forts around it,

5.verse: and laid siege to the city for two years.

6.verse: Then finally, on the ninth day of the fourth month, when the famine in the city was very serious, with the last of the food entirely gone,

7.verse: the people in the city tore a hole in the city wall and all the soldiers fled from the city during the night, going out by the gate between the two walls near the king’s gardens (for the city was surrounded by the Chaldeans), and made a dash for it across the fields, toward Arabah.

8.verse: But the Chaldean soldiers chased them and caught King Zedekiah in some fields near Jericho—for all his army was scattered from him.

9.verse: They brought him to the king of Babylon who was staying in the city of Riblah in the kingdom of Hamath, and there judgment was passed upon him.

10.verse: He made Zedekiah watch while his sons and all the princes of Judah were killed before his eyes.

11.verse: Then his eyes were gouged out, and he was taken in chains to Babylon and put in prison for the rest of his life.

12.verse: On the tenth day of the fifth month during the nineteenth year of the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, Nebuzaradan, captain of the guard, arrived in Jerusalem,

13.verse: and burned the Temple and the palace and all the larger homes,

14.verse: and set the Chaldean army to work tearing down the walls of the city.

15.verse: Then he took to Babylon, as captives, some of the poorest of the people—along with those who survived the city’s destruction, and those who had deserted Zedekiah and had come over to the Babylonian army, and the tradesmen who were left.

16.verse: But he left some of the poorest people to care for the crops as vinedressers and plowmen.

17.verse: The Babylonians dismantled the two large bronze pillars that stood at the entrance of the Temple, and the bronze laver and bronze bulls on which it stood, and carted them off to Babylon.

18.verse: And he took along all the bronze pots and kettles, the ash shovels used at the altar, the snuffers, spoons, bowls, and all the other items used in the Temple.

19.verse: He also took the firepans, the solid gold and silver candlesticks, and the cups and bowls.

20.verse: The weight of the two enormous pillars, the laver, and twelve bulls was tremendous. They had no way of estimating it. (They had been made in the days of King Solomon.)

21.verse: For the pillars were each 27 feet high and 18 feet in circumference, hollow, with 3-inch walls.

22.verse: The top 7½ feet of each column had bronze carvings, a network of bronze pomegranates.

23.verse: There were 96 pomegranates on the sides, and on the network round about there were a hundred more.

24.verse: The captain of the guard took along with him as his prisoners: Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah his assistant, the three chief Temple guards, one of the commanding officers of the army, seven of the king’s special counselors discovered in the city, the secretary of the general-in-chief of the Jewish army (who was in charge of recruitment), and sixty other men of importance found hiding.

25.verse: The captain of the guard took along with him as his prisoners: Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah his assistant, the three chief Temple guards, one of the commanding officers of the army, seven of the king’s special counselors discovered in the city, the secretary of the general-in-chief of the Jewish army (who was in charge of recruitment), and sixty other men of importance found hiding.

26.verse: He took them to the king of Babylon at Riblah,

27.verse: where the king killed them all. So it was that Judah’s exile was accomplished.

28.verse: The number of captives taken to Babylon in the seventh year of Nebuchadnezzar’s reign was 3,023.

29.verse: Then, eleven years later, he took 832 more;

30.verse: five years after that he sent Nebuzaradan, his captain of the guard, and took 745—a total of 4,600 captives in all.

31.verse: On February 25 of the thirty-seventh year of the imprisonment in Babylon of Jehoiachin, king of Judah, Evil-merodach, who became king of Babylon that year, was kind to King Jehoiachin and brought him out of prison.

32.verse: He spoke pleasantly to him and gave him preference over all the other kings in Babylon;

33.verse: he gave him new clothes and fed him from the king’s kitchen as long as he lived.

34.verse: And he was given a regular allowance to cover his daily needs until the day of his death.
